questions.text: Which of the following signs is not a specific sign of hanging?

choices.text: Ligature mark above the thyroid cartilage

questions.solution:
Amussat's sign is not a specific sign of hanging.

Amussat's sign is typically a transverse laceration of the intimal layer of carotid arteries described in cases of hanging. Subtotal laceration of the carotid artery is not strictly specific for hanging and can also be caused by:

  • Blunt neck trauma,
  • Extreme overstretching, or
  • Whiplash-injuries.

External post-mortem findings of hanging:

  • Cyanosis
  • Tardieu spots – petechiae over face
  • Le facie sympathique – Eyes remain open, and the pupil remains dilated due to compression of the cervical sympathetic chain on the same side. It indicates antemortem hanging.
  • Dribbling of saliva from the angle of the mouth, which is a confirmatory sign of antemortem hanging.
  • Ligature mark is above the thyroid cartilage, incomplete, bilaterally symmetrical and directed obliquely upward
  • Glove and stocking hypostasis

questions.text: Which space in the neck represented by numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4 in the image below, is known as danger space?
questions.solution:
The danger space of neck is number 3 which extends from the skull base to the diaphragm.

Danger space in neck: The danger space or alar space is the space that is present between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia.

The common name originates from the risk that an infection in this space can spread directly to the thorax, and, due to being a space continuous on the left and right, can furthermore allow infection to spread easily to either side.

Boundaries:

  • Anterior: Alar fascia
  • Posterior: Prevertebral fascia
  • Superior: Clivus
  • Inferior: Posterior mediastinum at the level of the diaphragm

Other options :

  • Prevertebral space extends from the base of the skull to the coccyx.
  • Retropharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation.
  • Parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the hyoid bone and submandibular gland.

Cervical fascia:

The cervical fascia in the neck consists of superficial fascia and various layers of deep fascia, which encloses several spaces.

The superficial cervical fascia is a zone of loose connective tissue, between the dermis and deep cervical fascia.

The deep cervical fascia includes three layers:

  • The superficial layer of deep cervical fascia also known as investing layer of deep fascia or parotidomasseteric fascia.
  • The middle layer of deep cervical fascia also called pretracheal fascia/ visceral fascia/ buccopharyngeal fascia.
  • The deep layer of deep cervical fascia also called prevertebral fascia. The alar fascia is a layer of fascia, sometimes described as part of the prevertebral fascia, lies in front of it.

Spaces in the neck:

Various fascial planes divide the neck into several spaces, which include

  • Spaces which extend in the entire length of the neck:
    • Prevertebral space
    • Retropharyngeal space
    • Carotid space
  • Spaces in the suprahyoid region of neck:
    • Buccal space
    • Parapharyngeal space
    • Parotid space
    • Pharyngeal mucosal space
    • Masticator space
  • Spaces in the infrahyoid region of the neck
    • Anterior cervical space
    • Posterior cervical space
    • Visceral space

questions.text: Time dependent killing and nil/minimal post antibiotic effect is seen with
questions.solution:
Time-dependent killing and nil/minimal post-antibiotic effect are seen with vancomycin.

Time dependent killing (TDK) means antimicrobial action depends on the length of time the concentration remains above the minimum inhibitory concentration. This is exhibited by beta lactam antibiotics and macrolides. For these drugs, multiple daily doses are preferred over single dose.

Post antibiotic effect (PAE): After exposure of an organism to the antibiotic, its growth stops. The growth resumes after a lag period when it is placed in the antibiotic-free medium. This signifies that the effect of antibiotics is present even when their concentration is below minimum inhibitory concentration. This phenomenon is post antibiotic effect.

Antibiotics with TDK with prolonged PAE:

  • Azithromycin
  • Clindamycin
  • Telithromycin
  • Linezolid
  • Macrolides
  • Tetracyclines
  • Streptogramin
  • Tigecycline.

Antibiotics with TDK with minimal/no PAE:

  • Beta-lactams
  • Vancomycin.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies?
questions.solution:
Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in vulval carcinomas.

This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even without palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in early diagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection.

A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphatic drainage.

Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are :

  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Penile carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

Lymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.

questions.text: All are true about dexmedetomidine except

choices.text: It can be administered as IV infusion.
Dry mouth is a side effect.

questions.solution:
Dexmedetomidine is a centrally acting, relatively selective alpha2-adrenergic agonist.

It can be administered as I.V infusion.

It is indicated for:

  • Sedation of initially intubated and mechanically ventilated patients during treatment in an intensive care setting. Administer dexmedetomidine by continuous infusion not to exceed 24 hours.
  • Sedation of non-intubated patients prior to and/or during surgical and other procedures.

It has a half-life of 2-3 hours and is metabolized in the liver.

Side effects are similar to those with clonidine such as, hypotension, bradycardia, and dry mouth.

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution:
The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%.

The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke.

Thus, EF = Volume ejected / End diastolic volume × 100

The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus,

EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) − End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) × 100

In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle,

EDV = 130 ml

ESV = 52 ml

Substituting these values in the above equation we get,

EF = (130 − 52 / 130) × 100

 = (3 / 5) × 100

 = 0.6 × 100

 = 60%

Related information:

The ejection fraction is a valuable index of the ventricular function. It is measured by injecting radionuclide-labeled red blood cells and imaging the volume of the blood at the end of diastole and the end of systole (equilibrium radionuclide angiocardiography), or by computed tomography.

The normal left ventricular ejection fraction is 50% to 70%.

In heart failure, ejection fraction may be preserved or reduced,

  • Preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) – also referred to as diastolic heart failure. The heart muscle contracts normally but the ventricles do not relax as they should during ventricular filling (or when the ventricles relax).
  • Reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) – also referred to as systolic heart failure. The heart muscle does not contract effectively and less oxygen-rich blood is pumped out to the body.

LVEF Assessment:

The American college of cardiology (ACC), gives the cardiac function and their corresponding ejection fractions

  • Hyperdynamic = LVEF greater than 70%
  • Normal = LVEF 50% to 70% (midpoint 60%)
  • Mild dysfunction = LVEF 40% to 49% (midpoint 45%)
  • Moderate dysfunction = LVEF 30% to 39% (midpoint 35%)
  • Severe dysfunction = LVEF less than 30%

questions.text: The image of a stillborn foetus is as seen below. All are true about this condition except:

choices.text: Four times more common in girls than boys
Approximately 75% of these tumors are malignant
Develop embryologically from multipotent cells in Hensen’s node

questions.solution:
The image is of Sacrococcygeal teratoma.

Approximately 75% of these tumors are mature teratomas (benign), and about 12% are unequivocally malignant and lethal. The remainder is immature teratomas.

  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma (SCT) is the most common tumor of the newborn with an incidence of 1 in 35,000 to 40,000 live births.
  • In the newborn, the sacrococcygeal site is located at the base of the tailbone (coccyx) and it is the most common location of teratomas in newborns.
  • Neonates have a 2-5% risk of malignancy that increases to 50% at one year and nearly 100% after 5 years of age.
  • It is 4 times as common in girls than boys.

questions.text: All are true regarding Corrosive esophagitis except:

choices.text: Absence of oral Injury does not exclude possible esophageal involvement
Early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to assess and grade the mucosal  injury
Glucocorticoids improves the clinical outcome of acute corrosive esophagitis
Healing of more severe grades of caustic injury is commonly associated with severe stricture formation

questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids have not been shown to improve the clinical outcome of acute corrosive esophagitis and are not recommended.

Corrosive esophagitis:

  • Caustic esophageal injury from ingestion of alkali or acid and can be accidental or from attempted suicide.
  • The absence of oral injury does not exclude possible esophageal involvement. Thus, early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to assess and grade the injury to the esophageal mucosa.
  • Severe corrosive injury may lead to esophageal perforation, bleeding, stricture, and death.
  • Glucocorticoids have not been shown to improve the clinical outcome of acute corrosive esophagitis and are not recommended.
  • Healing of more severe grades of caustic injury is commonly associated with severe stricture formation and often requires repeated dilatation.
  • Treatment is supportive

questions.text: Kraissl’s lines are

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.solution:
Kraissl's lines are relaxed tension lines in the skin. They lie perpendicular to the long axis of the underlying muscle. They were described in living individuals and reflect underlying muscle action.

Image of Kraissl's lines: 

Langer's lines correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis and are generally parallel to the orientation of the underlying muscle fibers. They were described in cadavers in reference to rigor mortis.

Image of Langer's lines: 

Borge's lines are also relaxed skin tension lines observed by pinching the skin in living individuals.

Borge's lines and Kraissl's lines are a better guide for elective incisions in the face and body than Langer's lines.

Linear incisions in the skin tend to have variable degrees of gaping. When a circular skin incision is performed, the skin defect acquires an elliptical configuration. By aligning circular incisions perpendicular to the muscle action, surgeons can minimize tension on the wound edges, reduce the risk of scar contracture, and achieve better cosmetic results. 

Difference between Kraissl's line and Langer's line

Kraissl's line Langer's line
Described in living individuals Described in cadavers
Lie perpendicular to the long axis of the underlying muscle Correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers 
Reflects the action of the underlying muscle They are skin tension vectors observed in the stretched skin of cadavers exhibiting rigor mortis

questions.text: A cancer chemotherapy patient has to have her intravenous port revised after it becomes blocked and the catheter is found to contain bacterial contaminants. Which of the following attributes is most likely to be a factor in this pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Catheters, shunts and prosthetic devices which are left in the body long-term, are almost always coated with Teflon which is extremely slippery.

Organisms which are capable of adherence to Teflon (or the enamel of teeth), do so by creation of a biofilm, which allows them to change the surface tension of the liquid around them and thereby “glue” themselves to the material.

Other options:

Option b: Ergosterol is the major sterol in the cell wall of fungi, and is important in membrane integrity, but not adherence.

Option c: Peptidoglycan is the cell wall material of bacteria, and is responsible for the shape of bacteria, but not their adherence.

Option d: IgA proteases can assist in the adherence of bacteria to mucosal surfaces, but would not be important in adherence to an intravenous catheter.

questions.text: According to various types of thyroplasty as described by Isshiki, type III thyroplasty refers to:
questions.solution:
Relaxation / shortening of vocal cord is a type III thyroplasty procedure.

Thyroplasty is a phonosurgical technique which aims to improve the voice by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

  • Type I: Medialization of vocal cord
  • Type II: Lateralization of vocal cord
  • Type III: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
  • Type IV: Elongation or tensioning of the vocal cord

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with history of several episodes of unilateral elevation of IOP between 40 and 50 mm Hg range. During these episodes, fine keratic precipitates and faint flare are noted. A mild ciliary flush is also noted. No iris changes are seen. Each episode seems to respond well to topical corticosteroids and topical and systemic aqueous suppression. What is the most likely cause of his episodic glaucoma?
questions.solution:
• The clinical picture given is characteristic of Posner-Schlossmann syndrome also called Glaucomatocyclitic crisis.
  • It is an acute, recurrent, very mild uveitis associated with secondary glaucoma. The glaucoma is characteristically out of proportion to the inflammation.

Clinical picture:

  • Patients present with unilateral mild ocular discomfort, some blurring of vision, and halos in a white eye with open angles.
  • The intraocular pressure is very high, often between 40 and 50 mmHg.
  • Inflammation is minimal, with some aqueous flare, occasional cells and a few small, flat non-pigmented keratic precipitates inferiorly.
  • Posterior synechiae or peripheral anterior synechiae do not form.
  • The inflammation often manifests several days after the intraocular pressure rises.
  • The attacks resolve in days to weeks, and recurrence is common.

Note: Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis can present with a similar picture but with iris hypochromia and gray-white nodules on the anterior iris.

questions.text: The AMAN variant of the Guillian Barre syndrome differs from the AIDP, in that, in the former the complement deposition along with IgG antibodies occurs at:
questions.solution:
• In AMAN (Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy), the pattern is different in that complement is deposited along with IgG at the nodes of Ranvier along large motor axons.
  • In AIDP (Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy), an early step in the initiation of tissue damage appears to be complement deposition along the outer surface of the Schwann cell.
  • Activation of complement initiates a characteristic vesicular disintegration of the myelin sheath and also leads to the recruitment of activated macrophages, which participate in damage to myelin and axons.

questions.text: At plasma para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) concentrations of lower than transport maximum (Tm), PAH?

choices.text: Secretion rate equals PAH excretion rate
Concentration in the renal vein is close to zero
Concentration in the renal vein equals PAH concentration in the renal artery

questions.solution:
• At plasma PAH concentrations that are lower than transport maximum (Tm), PAH concentration in the renal vein is nearly zero because the sum of filtration plus secretion removes virtually all PAH from the renal plasma.
  • Thus, the PAH concentration in the renal vein is less than that in the renal artery because most of the PAH entering the kidney is excreted in urine.
  • PAH clearance is greater than inulin clearance because PAH is filtered and secreted whereas inulin is only filtered.

Calculation of reabsorption and secretion rates:

  • The reabsorption or secretion rate is the difference between the amount filtered across the glomerular capillaries and the amount excreted in urine. 

It is calculated with the following equations:

  1. Filtered load = Glomerular Filtration Rate x Plasma Concentration
  2. Excretion rate = V (urine) x Ux
  • Where,
  • V = Urine flow rate in mL/min
  • Ux = Concentration of solute X in urine in mg/mL

3. Reabsorption rate = Filtered load – Excretion rate

4. Secretion rate = Excretion rate – Filtered load

Thus from the above equations it is clear that,

  • If the filtered load is greater than the excretion rate (FL > UV or UV/FL < 1), then the solute is reabsorbed along the tubule.
  • If excretion is greater than the filtered load (UV > FL or UV/FL > 1), then the substance is secreted by the tubule.

Transport maximum:

  • Denoted as Tm or Tmax, it refers to the point at which increases in concentration of a substance do not result in an increase in movement of a substance across a cell membrane.
  • In renal physiology, the concept of transport maximum is often discussed in the context of glucose and PAH.
  • For both substances (as with all substances), the quantity excreted can be determined with the following equation:
  • Excretion = (filtration + secretion) - reabsorption
  • The proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron has protein channels that reabsorb glucose, and others that secrete para-aminohippuric acid (PAH). However, its ability to do so is proportionate to the channel proteins available for the transport.
  • Glucose is not secreted, so excretion = filtration - reabsorption. Both filtration and reabsorption are directly proportional to the concentration of glucose in the plasma.
  • PAH is not reabsorbed and is secreted, so excretion = filtration + secretion. As with glucose, the transfer is at the proximal tubule, but in the opposite direction: from the peritubular capillaries to the lumen. At low levels, all the PAH is transferred, but at high levels, the transport maximum is reached, and the PAH takes longer to clear.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found to have elevated cholesterol levels of 345 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 42, and also had greatly elevated cholesterol levels throughout his life. The physician put the patient on lovastatin. After 2 weeks his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The nature of the elevated cholesterol in this patient is most likely due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has familial hypercholesterolemia due to a mutated LDL receptor. This type of type II hypercholesterolemia is the most common form of familial dyslipidemia. 

Lovastatin is an inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase. HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors cause cells to decrease the rate of cholesterol synthesis. Lower cellular levels of cholesterol cause a decreased conversion of cholesterol to cholesterol esters (by the ACAT reaction) for storage and increased production of LDL receptors. An increased number of receptors will cause more LDL to be taken up by cells from the circulation and degraded by lysosomes. Thus, blood cholesterol levels will decrease. Blood triacylglycerol levels will also decrease but not to a great extent because LDL contains only small amounts of triacylglycerol. Also, the patient most likely is heterozygous for a mutation in the LDL receptor. If the patient were homozygous for such a mutation, then lovastatin would not reduce circulating cholesterol levels, as there would be no functional LDL receptors to upregulate.

Other options:

  • Option A: The patient does not have a mutation in HMG-CoA reductase, as that is the target of lovastatin, and if an HMG-CoA reductase mutation were to reduce HMG-CoA reductase activity, then lovastatin would have little to no effect.
  • Option B: A mutation in protein kinase A, rendering it inactive, would not affect intracellular cholesterol synthesis (as it is the AMP-activated protein kinase that regulates the HMG-CoA reductase activity).
  • Option C: An inactivating mutation in ACAT (Acetyl-Coenzyme A acetyltransferase) would not lead to a reduction of circulating cholesterol in response to lovastatin as ACAT is important for esterification of the cholesterol to its other utilizable forms. 

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A bacterial isolate from a patient with chronic sinusitis is shown to be sensitive to amoxicillin on a Kirby-Bauer agar disk diffusion test. A follow-up determination of the MIC of the drug is reported back from the laboratory at 2 μg/ml with an MBC of 1 μg/ml. What is the correct interpretation of this data?

choices.text: The drug should be administered to the patient at 1 μg/ml
The drug should be administered to the patient at 2 μg/ml

questions.solution:
• The MIC (Minimal Inhibitory Concentration) is the most dilute amount of drug in which no growth of a bacterial isolate will occur.
  • The MBC (Minimal Bactericidal Concentration) of a drug is the most dilute amount of a drug in which there will be no colonial growth after the drug is removed.
  • In some cases the MBC may be equal to the MIC, but the amount of drug necessary to kill all bacteria is never less than the amount required to inhibit their growth temporarily. Thus MBC ≥ MIC.
  • In the above question, MIC is given as 2μg/ml and MBC is given as 1 μg/ml, that is here MIC > MBC, which is practically not possible, hence data is inaccurate and suggests a laboratory error.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a case of death due to bullet injuries. It showed linear fractures on the skull, as shown in the image below. Which of the following rules gives the sequence of the bullet injuries?
questions.solution:
The sequence of bullet injuries is given by Puppe’s rule.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present.The fracture lines created by every other shot extend only up to the fractured lines produced by the previous shot without continuing over them. Even though this rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. 

Other options:

Option A- M'Naghten rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not legally responsible if at the time of committing the crime, he/she was suffering from a defect of reason due to an abnormality of mind, which made him/her unaware of the nature and quality of the act he was doing or what he was doing was wrong. It comes under Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

Option C- Young's rule is used to calculate the dose of a drug for a child. It is calculated by multiplying the adult dose by the age in years and dividing the result by the sum of the child's age plus 12.

Option D- Durham's rule is a test to determine criminal responsibility and states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act is a product of mental disease (mental disorder) or mental defect (mental retardation).

questions.text: The patient whose hands are shown in the image below is developmentally delayed with a short, stocky build. Which of the following laboratory values is consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Considering the given options, based on the history and the image showing a short 4th metacarpal, the most likely diagnosis is pseudohypoparathyroidism. It is characterized by hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and high PTH. 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism occurs due to mutations in GNAS gene, leading to the formation of defective Gsα protein. This means that end-organ effects of PTH are hampered in patients suffering from pseudohypoparathyroidism. Even though PTH levels are high, it is not able to perform its normal function. Hypocalcemia is seen in these patients due to insufficient calcitriol production in the proximal renal tubules and consequent impaired intestinal calcium absorption. Urinary phosphate excretion is also impaired, causing hyperphosphatemia. 

Most patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism have characteristic skeletal features. These include short stature, early-onset obesity, round face, short metacarpals, and short metatarsals. This complex of skeletal abnormalities are referred to as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). Treatment of pseudohypoparathyroidism consists of a high dose of calcium and activated vitamin D (calcitriol).

Serum calcium Decreased Normal
Serum phosphate Increased Normal
Serum PTH Increased Normal
Urinary cAMP on administering PTH Decreased response

questions.text: In the pediatric ward,  a resident is evaluating a case of primary adrenal insufficiency who has failure to thrive, recurrent emesis, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bilateral adrenal calcification is noted radiologically. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wolman's disease.

It is a rare lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) that leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in most of the visceral organs.

Patients present in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: The lower fibres of the splenius capitis muscle inserts into the tips of the spinous processes of ________
questions.solution:
The splenius capitis muscle is a broad, strap like muscle in the back of the neck.

Origin: It arises from the mastoid process and the rough surface on the occipital bone just below the lateral third of the superior nuchal line. The fibres passes downwards and medially to reach the midline.

Insertion: The lower fibres insert into the tips of the spinous processes of the seventh cervical and upper three or four thoracic vertebrae and the intervening supraspinous ligaments.

Relations:

  • Forms the floor of the posterior neck triangle, lying between the sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius.
  • Deep to the trapezius.
  • Superficial to the semispinalis capitis and the longissimus capitis.

Innervation: Posterior rami of the 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves.

Blood supply:

  • Descending branch of occipital artery
  • Deep cervical artery

Action:

  • When acting unilaterally and synergistically with the sternocleidomastoid the muscle rotates the head to the same side.
  • When acting bilaterally it extends the head.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Ertugliflozin, which has been recently approved by the FDA, except

choices.text: It is indicated for the treatment of type I diabetes mellitus
It is a sodium glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor
It is not recommended in patients with an estimated GFR below 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2
Female genital mycotic infections are the most common among all adverse reactions

questions.solution:
• Ertugliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor indicated as an adjunct to diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • It is not used for the treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus or diabetic ketoacidosis.

Dosage and administration:

  • The recommended starting dose is 5 mg once daily, taken in the morning, with or without food.
  • The dosage can be increased to 15 mg once daily in those tolerating Ertugliflozin and needing additional glycemic control.
  • Do not use in patients with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) below 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.
  • Initiation and continued use are not recommended in patients with an eGFR persistently between 30 and less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m2.

Mechanism of action:

  • SGLT2 is the predominant transporter responsible for reabsorption of glucose from the glomerular filtrate back into the circulation.
  • Ertugliflozin is an inhibitor of SGLT2.
  • By inhibiting SGLT2, Ertugliflozin reduces renal reabsorption of filtered glucose and lowers the renal threshold for glucose, and thereby increases urinary glucose excretion.

Contraindication:

  • Severe renal impairment, end-stage renal disease, or dialysis. 
  • History of serious hypersensitivity reaction to Ertugliflozin.

Adverse reactions:

  • The most common adverse reactions associated with Ertugliflozin (incidence ≥ 5%) were female genital mycotic infections.

questions.text: SERM that is approved for use in dyspareunia in menopausal women is ______
questions.solution:
• Ospemifene is a SERM that is approved for use in dyspareunia in menopausal women.
  • Ospemifene has estrogenic agonist actions at vaginal epithelium that causes an increase in vaginal thickness and decreases the symptoms of dyspareunia.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: The nerve root that supplies the dermatomes of the middle and ring finger are respectively:
questions.solution:
The dermatomes of the middle and ring finger are supplied respectively by C7 and C8.

The following table shows the nerve roots and the dermatomes supplied.

questions.text: A lens has a focal length of 10 cms. What is the dioptric power of the lens?
questions.solution:
The dioptric power of the lens is reciprocal to its focal length, provided that the unit of measuring length is a metre.

Thus, 

D = 1 / f

Where,

D is the dioptric power of the lens, and f is the focal length in metre.

The focal length of the lens in the above question is 10 cms which is equal to 0.1 m.

Substituting the above value in the equation we get the dioptric power as,

D = 1 / 0.1 = 10 D

questions.text: Interpret the ECG shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The above ECG is suggestive of dextrocardia based on the following features.

  • Lead I is inverted with negative P wave, QRS complex & T wave.
  • Reversal of usual pattern of Lead aVR.
  • There is a loss of normal R-wave progression from V1 - V6 with dominant S waves throughout.
  • Right-axis deviation

Differential diagnosis : 

Accidental reversal of right and left arm electrodes may produce similar findings as dextrocardia in the limb leads, but with normal appearances in the precordial leads.

questions.text: A patient presented with carcinoma endometrium involving >50% myometrium, extending to the vagina but with no involvement of para-aortic and pre aortic nodes. What is the stage of her disease?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina but having no lymph node involvement is classified as stage IIIB.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with pain in her right shoulder and weight loss of 4 kg over the past four weeks. She had been taking non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs with only mild relief of her pain. She smoked 15–20 cigarettes per day. The chest X-ray is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Osteomyelitis affecting the right shoulder joint

questions.solution:
There are small lucencies in the head of the humerus and a large lucency in the lateral border of the scapula.There is only one breast shadow present (on the right), indicating that the patient has had a mastectomy, presumably for treatment of carcinoma of left breast.

In this case the lucencies have to be assumed to be secondary to disseminated breast carcinoma until proven otherwise. (Prostate, breast, and lung primaries account for 80% of all bone metastases).

In the exam always ensure both breast shadows are present on chest radiographs in female patients as evidence of a mastectomy may be a major clue to the answer.

questions.text: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refer to?

choices.text: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
Initiative for labour room quality improvement
Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all

questions.solution:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for labour room quality improvement.

There is enough evidence to support the fact that improving the quality of care in labour rooms, especially on the day of birth, is crucial to maternal and neonatal survival.

Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care being provided to the pregnant mother in the labour room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges besides district hospitals, and high delivery load sub-district hospitals, and community health centres.

It plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined. The goal is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in labour room and maternity OT, and ensure respectful maternity care.

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have wrinkled, patchy skin, a long thin body and long nails. Which of the following could be a cause for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of postmaturity syndrome which can occur due to placental sulphatase deficiency.

Etiology of post-term pregnancy:

  • Wrong dates - inaccurate LMP (most common)
  • Heredity
  • Previous prolonged pregnancy
  • Anencephaly
  • Placental sulphatase deficiency (leads to decreased estrogen synthesis)
  • Primipara/ elderly multipara

Features of postmaturity syndrome in a newborn:

  • Wrinkled, patchy, peeling skin, particularly prominent on the palms and soles
  • Long, thin body suggesting wasting
  • Long nails
  • Eyes open and unusually alert
  • Looks old and worried

Note: Placental aromatase deficiency causes disorder of sexual development of fetus.

questions.text: Grayhack shunt is established between _______
questions.solution:
Grayhack shunt is established between corpora cavernosa and saphenous vein.

  • Distal shunts should be performed first, because they can be done quickly in the emergency room with a True-Cut needle (Winter shunt). If this fails, an operative distal shunt can be performed (Al-Ghorab).
  • Proximal shunts such as Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein) or Quackel (proximal cavernosum spongiosum) shunts may be required in refractory cases.

Related Pearl: Surgical shunts for ischaemic priapism

Shunt site  Example 
Corpora glanular shunt  Winter / Al-Ghorab shunt 
Corpora spongiosal shunt  Quackel / Sacher shunt 
Corpora Saphenous shunt  Grayhack shunt 
Corpora dorsal vein shunt  Barry shunt

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the alexander’s law?

choices.text: It is used to assess patients with positional nystagmus
The drift of nystagmus is higher when the subject looks towards the side of slow component of the nystagmus compared with fast-phase direction
If the nystagmus is only present when the eyes are deviated in the direction of the fast phase, it is first-degree
Primary gaze nystagmus indicates first degree

questions.solution:
Alexander’s law refers to spontaneous nystagmus that occurs after an acute unilateral vestibular loss.

It states that in patients with spontaneous nystagmus due to an acute vestibular asymmetry, the slow phase velocity, or drift, of nystagmus is lower when the subject looks toward the side of the slow component of nystagmus compared with the fast phase direction.

Based on this lay, the spontaneous nystagmus is graded as follows:

  • First degree: The nystagmus is only present when the eyes are deviated in the direction of the fast phase
  • Second degree: In addition to that of first degree, the nystagmus is also present in primary gaze
  • Third degree: In addition to that of second degree, the nystagmus is also also present with the eyes deviated in the direction of the slow phase

Furthermore, the nystagmus should become more pronounced with the removal of optical fixation (as with Frenzel’s glasses).

questions.text: Modified Shock Index is calculated using?
questions.solution:
Modified Shock Index = HR/MAP (is better indicator to predict the mortality in Shock).

The Original Shock Index = HR/SBP 

Shock index is known as Hemodynamic Stability Indicator. Clinically, mean blood pressure can best represent tissue perfusion status. Diastolic blood pressure of a critical patient will decrease earlier than systolic blood pressure, and mean blood pressure can be an accurate predictor for disease severity.

HR: Heart rate

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her family history reveals that her mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 50 years, while her 42-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Further investigations ruled out familial adenomatous polyposis and confirmed the diagnosis of familial cancer. Which of the following genes is most likely to be mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome in which the gene MSH2 is likely to be mutated. 

Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and as well as endometrial, ovarian, gastric and small intestine cancers. This syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, mainly MLH1 and MSH2.

They occur commonly at a young age and mostly involve the right side. Histology shows:

  • Sessile serrated adenoma
  • Mucinous adenocarcinoma

It can be diagnosed by the Amsterdam II criteria or by genetic testing. 

Note- APC gene mutation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis and sporadic colonic cancer. The mechanism is due to a defect in APC/WNT pathway. 

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: The McLeod phenotype is associated with the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The Kell protein is very large protein made up of 720 amino acids and its secondary structure contains many different antigenic epitopes.
  • The absence of the Kell precursor protein (controlled by a gene on X chromosome) is associated with a rare condition called McLeod phenotype, which is characterized by acanthocytosis, shortened RBC survival, and a progressive form of muscular dystrophy that includes cardiac defects.
  • The Kx gene is linked to the 91-kDa component of the NADPH-oxidase on the X chromosome, deletion or mutation of which accounts for about 60% of cases of chronic granulomatous disease.

Other options:

Option a: The Duffy antigens are codominant alleles, Fya and Fyb that alsoserve as receptors for Plasmodium vivax. The lack of the Duffy antigen receptor for cytokines (DARC) is associatedwith mild neutropenia.

Option b: The Kidd antigens, Jka and Jkb, may elicit antibodies transiently. Adelayed hemolytic transfusion reaction that occurs with blood tested ascompatible is often related to delayed appearance of anti-Jka.

questions.text: In the given circuit of blood flow, the inward flow pressure is 100 mmHg and the outward flow pressure is 10 mmHg. Each of the parallel circuit of capillaries have resistance of 5 mmHg/mL/min. Calculate the flow across the circuit of blood vessels.
questions.solution:
In the given circuit of the blood flow, three capillary resistances are connected in parallel,

Hence the net resistance (R) can be calculated as

1 / R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

1 / R = 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5

Therefore,

Net resistance (R) = 5/3 mmHg/mL/min

Flow in any portion of the vascular system is equal to the effective perfusion pressure in that portion divided by the net resistance.

The effective perfusion pressure is the mean intraluminal pressure at the arterial end (inward flow pressure) minus the mean pressure at the venous end (outward flow pressure).

According to Ohm’s law,

The flow in any circuit can be calculated by the formula,

Flow = (100-10) / (5/3)

= 90 × 3/5

= 18 × 3

= 54 mL/min

questions.text: The reagent used to distinguish staphylococci from streptococci is
questions.solution:
• The staphylococci are aerobic while the streptococci are aerotolerant anaerobes.
  • Streptococci ferment even in the presence of high levels of oxygen and lack catalase.
  • A standard quick test involves mixing staphylococci with hydrogen peroxide. The catalase-positive staphylococci convert hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. The generation of oxygen bubbles indicates that the gram-positive coccus is a Staphylococcus rather than a Streptococcus.
  • A coagulase test uses the serum to see if fibrinogen is clotted is used to distinguish the coagulase-positive staphylococci from coagulase-negative staphylococci.
  • Oxidase is not the reagent but the reactor in the oxidase test.

questions.text: Identify the imaging shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Diffusion Tensor Imaging(DTI), an MRI-based neuroimaging.

It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain. White matter tracts of the brain include association fibres, commissural fibres, projection fibres, and subcortical fibres.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) spectroscopy is a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance used to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. It contains N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), choline, creatine, lipids and lactate.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

questions.text: In a patient with full-thickness burns of 40%, which of the following colloid-based formula should be used to transfuse proteins within 12 hours?
questions.solution:
• The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula:
    • 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion;
    • Periods of 4/4/4, 6/6 and 12 hours, respectively;
    • One portion to be given in each period.
  • Parkland formula is used to calculate the crystalloid volume to be given in the first 24 hours.
  • Wallace rule of nine is used to calculate the percentage of burn.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear is similar to that shown in the illustration below. Which of the following additional abnormalities is expected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear. A history of anemia along with a family history of splenectomy strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies is an additional abnormality that can be expected here.

Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to defects in ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 proteins, leading to a defect in the red cell membrane that causes red cells to transform into spherocytes.

The patients usually present with anemia, gallstones, splenomegaly, and jaundice. Aplastic crisis might occur due to parvovirus infection. 

Spherocytosis is the common finding, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. Other features are increased reticulocyte count, Howell-Jolly bodies which are dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs, marrow erythroid hyperplasia, and hemosiderosis. 

Laboratory findings are increased normal or slight decrease in mean corpuscular volume (MCV), increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC >34), and increased red cell distribution width (RDW >14%).

Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. 

Heinz bodies are denatured precipitates that cause damage to the RBC membrane. These cells passing through splenic cords get the characteristic appearance of bite cells. They are seen in cases of chemical poisoning, drug toxicity, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. 

The image below shows Heinz bodies and bite cells.
