questions.text: All of the following are contents of mesorectum except:
questions.solution:
Inferior rectal vein is not a content of mesorectum.

 

The contents of mesorectum are:

  • Loose adipose connective tissue
  • Superior rectal artery and its branches
  • Superior rectal vein and tributaries.
  • Lymphatic vessels and nodes along superior rectal artery
  • Branches from inferior mesenteric plexus to innervate rectum.

questions.text: A 23 year old female patient presented with diarrhea since 3 days. On examination there were pigmentary changes in skin, hair loss and nail atrophy. On further investigation she was found to have polyps in stomach. Probable diagnosis is ________:
questions.solution:
Combination of gastrointestinal polyposis in association with alopecia, cutaneous pigmentation, and atrophy of the fingernails and toenails suggest diagnosis of Cronkite-Canada syndrome.

  • It is an acquired disorder.
  • Diarrhea is a prominent symptom, and vomiting, malabsorption and protein-losing enteropathy may occur.
  • Polyps are found throughout GIT, most commonly in stomach with characteristic esophageal sparing.
  • Supportive care and steroids for disease recurrence is recommended.

questions.text: Non invasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis  include:
questions.solution:
FibroTest is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporates haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A-I, and α2-macroglobulin. 

Aspartate aminotransferase/Platelet ratio and Forns index are tests to estimate the risk of developing liver fibrosis.

Tests for estimating risk of developing hepatic fibrosis:

  • AST/Platelet ratio
  • Forns Index
  • Fib-4
  • Cirrhosis determinant score

Test for detecting hepatic fibrosis:

  • FibroTest (also called Fibrosure)

Note: Serum laminin and serum hyaluronidase are non specific and is not preferred as a test to detect hepatic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia. 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

  • Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance
  • Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance

A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. 

In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: Optic atrophy and progressive sensorineural hearing loss are characteristic of ________
questions.solution:
• Norrie disease (ND) is a rare X-linked recessive disease, characterized by optic atrophy and progressive sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Most males develop sensorineural hearing loss during adolescence.

Other options:

  • Option a: Alport’s syndrome shows glomerulonephritis with variable SNHL in about 50 percent.
  • Option c: Pendred’s syndromeis associated with thyroid abnormalities and large vestibular aqueduct syndrome (LVAS)
  • Option d: Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is a condition that causes profound hearing loss from birth and arrhythmia. This disorder is a form of long QT syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about prokaryotic cells except:

choices.text: Cell wall composed of peptidoglycan-containing muramic acid
They are haploid with a single chromosome

questions.solution:
Prokaryotic cells have coupled transcription and translation, which means that ribosomes bind to the mRNA and protein synthesis (translation) begins while the mRNA is still being synthesized (transcription). Uncoupled transcription and translation is a feature shown by eukaryotic cells.

Characteristic features of prokaryotes:

  • Have no organelles, no membrane-enclosed nucleus, and no histones; in rare cases, they contain complex phospholipids, sphingolipids, and sterols.
  • Have a cell wall composed of peptidoglycan-containing muramic acid.
  • Have 70S ribosomes composed of 30S and 50S subunits.
  • Are haploid with a single chromosome.
  • Have short-lived, unprocessed mRNA.
  • Have coupled transcription and translation, which means that ribosomes bind to the mRNA and protein synthesis (translation) begins while the mRNA is still being synthesized (transcription).

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman in labour was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the fetus was found to be in occipitoposterior position. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for progress of labour

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for pregnant women in labour whose fetus is in occipitoposterior position is to wait and watch for progress of labour. In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle and the baby is born as occipitoanterior.

Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior is made, labour is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and favourable pelvis.

Indications of caesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labour
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about ozenoxacin, a topical quinolone antimicrobial which has been recently approved by FDA?

choices.text: It is indicated for treatment of impetigo due to Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes
Can be applied for pediatric patients 2 months of age and older
It acts by inhibition of bacterial DNA replication enzymes, DNA gyrase A and topoisomerase IV

questions.solution:
Ozenoxacin is a quinolone antimicrobial indicated for the topical treatment of impetigo caused due to Staphylococcus aureus (including methicillin resistant isolates) or Streptococcus pyogenes in adult and pediatric patients 2 months of age and older.

Dosage and administration:

  • Apply a thin layer of ozenoxacin topically to the affected area twice daily for five days.
  • Affected area may be up to 100 cm2 in adult and pediatric patients 12 years of age and older or
  • 2% of the total body surface area and not exceeding 100 cm2 in pediatric patients less than 12 years of age.

Mechanism of action:

  • Ozenoxacin is a quinolone antimicrobial drug.
  • The mechanism of action involves the inhibition of bacterial DNA replication enzymes, DNA gyrase A and topoisomerase IV.
  • Ozenoxacin has been shown to be bactericidal against S. aureus and S. pyogenes organisms.

Resistance:

  • Resistance can arise through mutations of one or more of the genes that encode DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV. 
  • Resistant organisms will typically carry a combination of mutations within gyrA and parC subunits.

questions.text: Transanal local excision can be done in rectal carcinoma patients with all of the following tumour features except ____.

choices.text: Tumor within 8 cm of the anal verge
T2 tumor without lymph node involvement

questions.solution:
T2 rectal cancers are managed by transabdominal resection. 

Transanal local excision is recommended for selected T1, N0 early-stage cancers which fulfill the following criteria:

  1. Small (<3 cm), well- to moderately-differentiated tumors
  2. Tumors within 8 cm of the anal verge
  3. Tumors limited to <30% of the rectal circumference
  4. Tumors with no evidence of nodal involvement
  5. Full-thickness excision must be feasible.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing. She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers and toes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies to which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins (anti-centromere antibodies).

CREST syndrome is characterized by the following:

  • Calcinosis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing  the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient came back to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is ______.

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests  a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by

  • Drainage of fluid collections (Pigtail insertion and drainage) and
  • Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment Strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about blood supply of the oesophagus except:

choices.text: Thoracic part of the oesophagus drains into hemiazygous vein
Cervical part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from inferior thyroid artery
Abdominal part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from right gastric artery
Abdominal part of the oesophagus drains into left gastric vein

questions.solution:
The abdominal part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from the left gastric artery.

Blood supply of the oesophagus:

Arterial supply:

  • Cervical part: Inferior thyroid artery
  • Thoracic part: Bronchial and Oesophageal branches of descending thoracic aorta
  • Abdominal part: Left gastric artery

Venous drainage:

  • Cervical part: Inferior thyroid veins
  • Thoracic part: Azygous veins and hemiazygous veins
  • Abdominal part: Left gastric and upper short gastric veins and to a lesser extent drains into azygous and hemiazygous veins

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries?
questions.solution:
Fracture is not included in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries.

Marshall’s triad is associated with blast injuries. The triad includes:

  • Bruises
  • Abrasions
  • Puncture lacerations

questions.text: A patient presented with cataract as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true about the patient?

choices.text: A Vossius ring can be found on the anterior lens capsule
The patient may have elevated intraocular pressure (IOP)
Patients may also have involvement of their liver and brain

questions.solution:
• The image shows sunflower cataract, which is characteristic of Wilson’s disease.
  • Wilson disease is a multisystem disease as a result of abnormal copper metabolism. Copper accumulates in the anterior lens capsule producing the sunflower appearance. Copper deposition in Descemet membrane produces the brownish Kayser–Fleischer ring.
  • Systemic manifestations include cirrhosis, renal impairment, and degeneration of the basal ganglia.
  • The mainstay of therapy for Wilson disease is pharmacologic treatment with chelating agents such as D-penicillamine and trientine.  Other agents include sodium dimercaptosuccinate, dimercaptosuccinic acid, zinc, and tetrathiomolybdate.  Zinc salts act as inductors of methallothioneins, which favor a negative copper balance and a reduction of free plasmatic copper.

questions.text: In breast cancer, FISH for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following IHC staining for Her-2/neu?

choices.text: Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status

questions.solution:
• Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) should be performed in all cases of breast tumors with immunohistochemistry (IHC) score of 2+.
  • Her-2/neu IHC interpretation: 
    • 1+ = Negative
    • 2+ = Equivocal-> FISH is done to differentiate whether the tumor cells are positive or negative for Her-2 Neu expression.
    • 3+ = +ve Her 2 Neu. (Circumferential complete membrane staining in >10% of tumor cells)

This is a recent Nov. AIIMS Question. Concept of immunohistochemistry and ways to determine the presence of different hormonal and growth factor receptor play a major role in the prognosis of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding acute compartment syndrome of the forearm?

choices.text: It is defined by compartment pressure of >30 mm of Hg
Whiteside’s technique is used to measure compartment pressure
Mobile wad of Henry compartment is most commonly involved
Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Mobile wad of Henry refers to the lateral compartment of the forearm and is not commonly associated in acute compartment syndrome. Volar (anterior) compartment is most commonly involved.

Whiteside described a technique for measuring compartment pressures using an 18-gauge needle, saline syringe, three-way stopcock, and a mercury manometer.

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice and should be performed when the difference between compartment and diastolic pressure is less than 30 mm of mercury or if compartment pressure is more than 30 mmhg.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: An infant presents to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing, constipation, and anorexia. Upon examination, the physician notes flaccid paralysis. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin?

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2)

questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical history of flaccid paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, tox screen of stool, and age are suggestive of infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome) caused by Clostridium botulinum.

The flaccid paralysis is due to the toxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine.

Clostridium botulinum in adults causes food poisoning.

Other options:

Option a: ADP ribosylation of eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2) describes toxins found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Option b: ADP ribosylation of Gi, an inhibitory subunit of the G protein describes Bordetella pertussis.

Option c: ADP ribosylation of GTP-binding protein describes the toxins found in ETEC and Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: An 87-year-old woman who is taking multiple medications for her “heart disease” is prescribed gentamicin for diverticulitis.  After a few days of taking the antibiotic, she complains of dizziness and tinnitus. What “heart medication” might she be on?
questions.solution:
Ototoxicity, as demonstrated by tinnitus and dizziness, is a common side effect of loop diuretics, especially ethacrynic acid.  This effect is further increased when aminoglycoside antibiotics are added to the regimen.

Other options:

  • Spironolactone is not associated with tinnitus.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide can cause gout in susceptible individuals.
  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is not indicated in patients with heart disease, especially congestive heart failure (CHF).

questions.text: During the infant death assessment, Ploucquet’s test involves _______

choices.text: Change in the partial weight of the lungs
Presence of air in the stomach and duodenum
Change in the specific gravity of the lungs

questions.solution:
During the assessment of the infant death, the Ploucquet’s test involves change in partial weight of the lungs.

Ploucquet’s Test: The blood flow in the lung beds is so increased after breathing that their weight is almost doubled from 1/70 of the body weight before respiration to 1/35 after respiration. The increase in weight is not constant and is not a reliable indication of breathing.

questions.text: Which of the following values of peak inspiratory nasal flow is suggestive of moderate nasal obstruction?
questions.solution:
• Peak inspiratory nasal flow is assessed using a peak flowmeter which is similar to the expiratory one used for assessment of lower airway function.
  • The device has a mask that is placed over the nose and mouth.
  • With the mouth closed, the patient is asked to take a deep breath in through the nose.
  • The measurement is repeated for two more times, and the best of the three readings is taken as the final result.

Interpretation:

  • <50 L/min = severe nasal obstruction
  • 50–80 L/min = moderate nasal obstruction
  • 80–120 L/min = mild nasal obstruction
  • >120 L/min = normal

questions.text: Senile retinoschisis and Juvenile X Linked Retinoschisis (JXLR) occur at ____ and ______ respectively.

choices.text: Nerve fiber layer, Outer plexiform layer
Inner plexiform layer, Outer plexiform layer
Outer plexiform layer, Nerve fiber layer
Outer nuclear layer, Inner plexiform layer

questions.solution:
Retinoschisis is an actual splitting of the cellular layers of the retina.

  • Senile retinoschisis is characterized by splitting of the retina at the level of the outer plexiform layer.
  • The condition is common in those with hypermetropia.
  • It is usually usually bilateral, occurring in the lower temporal quadrant and progressing slowly.
  • It produces an absolute field defect starting in the upper nasal field and enlarging towards the fixation point.Rarely retinoschisis may affect the macula, causing loss of central field.
  • Breaks may occur in the inner or outer layers of a retinoschisis.

Juvenile retinoschis is also called Juvenile X Linked Retinoschisis (JXLR)is a hereditary disorder in whichthere is a splitting of the retina in the nerve fibre layer with the development of nerve fibre layer breaks. Thismay be associated with cystoid changes in the foveamanifesting as retinal folds radiating from the fovealcentre in a petalloid pattern.

questions.text: The following image shows the posterior aspect of the femur. The adductor brevis muscle is inserted at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The adductor brevis muscle is inserted at pectineal line and superior part of medial lip of linea aspera (the site marked as 4 in the above image) which lies lateral to the insertions of the pectineus above and adductor longus below (not shown in image), and medial to the insertion of the adductor magnus muscle.

The attachments marked in the above image are:

  1. Pectineus
  2. Gluteus maximus
  3. Adductor magnus
  4. Adductor brevis

Adductor brevis:

  • Origin: Anterior surface of inferior pubic ramus, inferior to origin of adductor longus
  • Insertion: Pectineal line and superior part of medial lip of linea aspera
  • Action: Adducts and flexes the thigh, and helps to laterally rotate the thigh
  • Innervation: Anterior division of the obturator nerve  (L 2 -3)
  • Vascular Supply: Profunda femoris artery distally and the artery to adductors proximally. Additionally the proximal part receives blood supply from the medial circumflex femoral artery. The deep surface of the muscle receives branches from the obturator artery

questions.text: A patient who underwent an intra-abdominal surgery is about to receive intraspinal opioid injection for analgesia. Which of the following drugs should not be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Remifentanil should not be used for intraspinal injection.

Remifentanil is formulated in combination with glycine. Glycine acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal dorsal horn that causes a reversible motor weakness when it is injected intrathecally.

For this reason, remifentanil is not approved for spinal or epidural use.

questions.text: Following a kidney transplant, a 24-year-old male patient is placed on cyclosporine but after 48 hours complains of serious nausea and diarrhea and has a sudden increase in transaminases. You switch him to tacrolimus but nausea persists and he complains of getting dizzy and has dyspnea. Which of the following immunosuppressive agents would be an alternate drug in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mycophenolate mofetil is the immunosuppressive agent that would be an alternate drug in this scenario indicated as a prophylaxis for transplant rejection. 

Mycophenolate mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly converted to mycophenolic acid. It is a selective, non-competitive, reversible inhibitor of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), an important enzyme in the de novo pathway of guanine nucleotide synthesis and a suitable alternative for managing transplant rejection in cases where cyclosporine or tacrolimus is not tolerated. 

Cyclosporine is commonly used for immunosuppression following transplantation to prevent organ rejection. However, it can cause side effects such as nausea, diarrhoea, and elevated liver enzymes. These symptoms are adverse effects of cyclosporine rather than indicative of treatment failure.

Azathioprine may be used as another alternative, although it is less commonly preferred due to its potential for myelosuppression.

When a patient experiences intolerable side effects with cyclosporine, tacrolimus is often used as an alternative. Tacrolimus, another effective immunosuppressant, can also cause nausea, dizziness, and dyspnea in some patients.

Other options:

Option B: Etanercept is a TNF-α antagonist used in rheumatoid arthiritis and Crohn’s disease.

Option C: Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 antibody that would be of little benefit following an organ transplant.

Option D: Basiliximab is an interleukin-2 receptor antagonist for activated T lymphocytes that may cause shortness of breath. As the patient has dyspnoea, the administration of basiliximab will further worsen his condition.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can cause corneal appearance as shown in the image, except
questions.solution:
• The above image shows cornea verticillata, which is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium seen in patients on long-term treatment with medication such as amiodarone, chloroquine, phenothiazines, and indomethacin.
  • The condition is also seen in patients with Fabry disease and its carrier state.
  • The whorl-like pattern shows the direction of migration of corneal epithelial cells.
  • It is usually asymptomatic, harmless and reversible on stopping the drug. However, sometimes it may cause glare and surface discomfort which responds to topical lubricants.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a suicide victim, comes to autopsy. Before dying, he had been despondent after being informed that he had an extremely aggressive brain tumor. There had been a recent onset of headache, seizures, and mental status changes, and MRI had demonstrated an infiltrating neoplasm invading the cerebral hemispheres and crossing the midline, with areas of necrosis and abnormal blood vessels. The autopsy confirms the MRI findings and also demonstrates hemorrhage and a pseudo palisade arrangement of tumor cells. Which of the following molecular findings would support a primary, rather than secondary, origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical history and investigations is suggestive of glioblastoma multiforme.
  • GBM is the most common primary intracranial neoplasm. This brain tumor has a very poor prognosis, with death occurring in less than 1 year.
  • Mutations in EGFR and PTEN are associated with primary GBM, whereas p53 mutations are frequently observed in secondary GBMs.
  • MGMT promoter methylation is not specifically linked to either primary or secondary GBM, but it predicts better response to treatment in GBMs because tumors cannot repair damage caused by alkylating agents.
  • NF2 mutations are common in meningiomas.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased urinary phosphate excretion. The injection​ of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hypoparathyroidism after thyroid surgery.

Low blood Ca2+ and high blood phosphate are consistent with hypoparathyroidism.

Lack of parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreases bone resorption, decreases renal reabsorption of Ca2+, and increases renal reabsorption of phosphate (causing low urinary phosphate).

Because the patient responded to exogenous PTH with an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), the G protein coupling the PTH receptor to adenylate cyclase is apparently normal. Consequently, pseudohypoparathyroidism is excluded.

Vitamin D intoxication would cause hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, while Vitamin D deficiency would cause hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

Hypoparathyroidism: It is most commonly a result of thyroid surgery, or it is congenital.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Decreased serum Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) and tetany
  • Increased serum phosphate (hyperphosphatemia)
  • Decreased urinary phosphate excretion

questions.text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. 

It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.

Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.

Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.

Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.text: Patella cubiti is an accessory bone present in which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Patella cubiti is an accessory bone present in the triceps near its insertion at the olecranon.

Note: Fabella is a sesamoid bone that develops in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle at the knee joint.

questions.text: All of the following parasites are transmitted by the vector shown in the image below except ______.
questions.solution:
The above image is of a tse-tse fly. Trypanosomabrucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense are transmitted by tsetse fly. Trypomastigote in the saliva of tsetse fly contaminates bite.

Trypanosoma cruzi is transmitted by Reduviid bug (kissing or cone bug; genus Triatoma), which passes trypomastigote (flagellated form) in feces, later scratching implants them in mucosa.

T. cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is apalutamide approved for?
questions.solution: Apalutamide is an androgen receptor inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true about fibrillar matrix of the connective tissue except:
1.	Type I collagen is the most abundant of all the collagens
2.	Types I, II, III, V, and XI collagens form fibrils
3.	Reticular fibres are principally formed of type II collagen
4.	Elastin fibres show banding pattern under electron microscopy
questions.solution:
• Statement 3 is false because, Reticular fibrils are formed mainly by type III collagen.
  • Statement 4 is false as elastin fibres arethin branching fibresand do not show banding pattern under electron microscopy.

Extracellular Matrix:

The term extracellular matrix includes extracellular components of connective and supportive tissues.  It includes:

  • Fibrillar matrix: Includes members of collagen family and elastin
  • Interfibrillar matrix: Includes glycosaminoglycans and a number of adhesive glycoproteins such as fibronectin, laminin, tenascin and vitronectin

Fibrillar matrix of connective tissue:

i) Collagen:

  • Collagens form approximately 30% of all the proteins in the body.
  • Types I, II, III, V and XI collagens form fibrils. Type I collagen is the most abundant of all collagens.
  • All collagens share common features such as, they contain high levels of hydroxyproline and all are composed of three polypeptides that form triple helices and are substantially modified post-translationally.
  • The collagen proteins are tough, thick, fibrous and non-branching proteins.
  • Under electron microscopy collagen type I, shows banding pattern, due to the fact that the bands of charged and uncharged amino acids are arranged across the fibres and are found repeated in longitudinal sections.

ii) Reticular fibres:

  • Reticular fibres are formed principally of type III collagen.
  • They are found in liver, kidney, lymphoreticular tissues (lymph nodes, spleen, etc.)

iii) Elastin:

  • They are less widely distributed than collagen, yellowish in colour.
  • Unlike collagen type I, they do not show banding pattern in the electron microscope.
  • They stain poorly with routine histological stains but are stained with orcein-containing preparations.

questions.text: All of the following statement are true about macimorelin, which has been recently approved by FDA, except:

choices.text: It is a growth hormone (GH) secretagogue receptor agonist
It is administered as single oral dose of 0.5 mg/kg for adults
The dose is administered as a reconstituted solution

questions.solution:
• Macimorelin is a growth hormone (GH) secretagogue receptoragonist which is indicated for the diagnosis of adult growth hormone deficiency.
  • The recommended dose is a single oral dose of 0.5 mg/kg of macimorelin.
  • The dose is administered as a reconstituted solution.

Procedure for performing the test:

  • The solution is prepared by mixing the drug in the water to prepare a solution with concentration of 0.5 mg/mL
  • The dosage to be administered is calculated at 0.5 mg/Kg and the required amount of the reconstituted solution is taken by syringe graduated in mL, i.e., if a patient weighs 70 Kg, then the dosage of the drug at 0.5 mg/Kg is 35 mg. As the concentration of the solution is 0.5 mg/mL, 70 mL of the solution contains 35 mg of drug.
  • Have the patient to drink the solution by a drinking glass within 30 seconds.
  • Observe the patient being tested per routine for the duration of the test.
  • Draw venous blood samples for GH determination at 30 minutes, 45 minutes, 60 minutes and 90 minutes after administration of macimorelin.
  • Prepare serum samples and send to a laboratory for growth hormone determinations.

Interpretation:

  • Maximally stimulated serum GH level of less than 2.8 ng/mL (i.e., at the 30, 45, 60 and 90 minute time points) following macimorelin administration confirms the presence of adult growth hormone deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy has eczema and thrombocytopenia. There is also a history of recurrent infection. His brother has similar abnormalities, but none of his three sisters is affected. Patients with this disorder are known to have impaired antibody response to which of the following types of antigen?
questions.solution:
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and poor antibody response to polysaccharide antigens.

  • X-linked recessive and only occurs in boys.
  • Petechiae, bloody diarrhoea, epistaxis may occur due to thrombocytopenia with small platelets.
  • Eczema usually begins in first month of life.
  • Recurrent infections with encapsulated bacteria due to immunodeficiency.
  • Increased incidence of autoimmune manifestations and malignancies.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is caused due to structural mutation with defective actin polymerization in haematopoietic cells as a result of deficient or dysregulated activity of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp).
  • There is poor antibody response to polysaccharide antigens.
  • Low Ig M but high Ig A and Ig E levels.

Treatment:

  • Bone marrow transplantation is considered as definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with a soft tissue tumor of the lower leg. The tumor closely approximates the knee joint but does not appear to arise within or communicate with the synovium. Microscopy reveals a spindled-cell proliferation with admixed epithelial components, and molecular testing shows an X;18 translocation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient has synovial sarcoma, which is a misnomer as the soft tissue malignancy does not appear to be related to the synovium.
  • It is commonly biphasic with both spindled and epithelial components demonstrable on both light microscopy and immunohistochemistry.
  • Monophasic sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with little cytoplasm but dense chromatin in tightly packed fascicles.
  • Immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing these tumours as the epithelial antigens (keratins) differentiate synovial sarcomas from other sarcomas.
  • The characteristic translocation involves X;18. While the demonstration of t(X;18) is required to confirm a diagnosis of synovial sarcoma, it is not entirely specific for this entity.

questions.text: Which of the following skin infections is caused by the organism shown below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Gram-positive cocci in clusters, suggestive of staphylococcus. It causes pemphigus neonatorum or bullous impetigo of the newborn.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by chronic, recurrent, very painful ulcers with undermined borders usually found on the lower limbs. It is usually associated with inflammatory bowel disease.

Option C: Impetigo herpetiformis is severe pustular psoriasis in pregnancy.

Option D: Ecthyma contagiosum is a contagious pustular dermatitis and a viral zoonotic disease caused by the parapox virus.

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

A. Direct infection of skin and adjacent tissues

  • Carbuncle
  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis
  • Impetigo
  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

questions.text: A 10-day old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is hyper-alert with mydriasis. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes and clonus. On investigations, a normal EEG is obtained. What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
Hyperactive tendon reflexes may be seen in stages 1 and 2; however, the infant is hyperalert with mydriasis and normal EEG findings in stage 1.

Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hour if progresses; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hour to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV presented with weakness affecting the left upper and lower limbs. On examination he was confused and had a temperature of 100.4°F. He had recently been treated for a Pneumocystis carinii infection. The CD4 count was 150/μl. CT scan of the brain with contrast revealed subcortical atrophy and multiple contrast-enhancing ring lesions in the cortex and subcortical areas. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

The CT scan is consistent with the diagnosis; the subcortical atrophy probably represents HIV encephalopathy. The exact cause of CNS involvement in HIV infection is largely influenced by the CD4 count.

  • Patients with CD4 counts >500/μl have benign and malignant brain tumours similar to those seen in immunocompetent patients.
  • Patients with a CD4 count of between 200/μl and 500/μl often have cognitive disorders associated with HIV such as HIV dementia and progressive leukoencephalopathy, which are not mass lesions.
  • Patients with a CD4 count <200/μl have either opportunistic CNS infections or HIV-related cerebral tumours.

Opportunistic infections include toxoplasmosis, TB, CMV and cryptococcal meningitis.

Toxoplasmosis is by far the most common cerebral mass lesion seen in HIV patients and is usually associated with multiple ring-enhancing lesions either in the cortico-medullary junction or around the basal ganglia.

Patients often have headaches, confusion and fever. Focal neurological signs or seizures are common. The other opportunistic infections rarely result in mass lesions in the absence of disseminated infection.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Primary CNS lymphoma does display some degree of contrast enhancement but it is usually nodular or patchy; however, lesions may be multiple and difficult to differentiate from toxoplasmosis. Thallium single photon emission computed tomography is useful in differentiating cerebral toxoplasmosis from cerebral lymphoma. Primary CNS lymphoma is rarer than cerebral toxoplasmosis in HIV infection. Generally, patients with multiple ring-enhancing lesions on the CT scan with mass effect are treated empirically for toxoplasma infection for two weeks with a combination of pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine. Failure of a radiological response (on CT scan) is an indication for brain biopsy to enable an alternative diagnosis such as lymphoma.

questions.text: The term ‘Monday morning fever ‘is generally used for the symptoms associated with poisoning by which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
The term ‘Monday morning fever ‘is generally used for the symptoms associated with Zinc poisoning. 

Monday morning fever

  • (Also called Smelter shakes/Brass chills/Metal fume fever) was described as early as 1669 in brass foundry workers as ‘brass foundryman’s ague’.
  • Symptoms of metal fume fever occur up to 24 hour after exposure to zinc oxide fumes.
  • It presents as an influenza-like illness with headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains. Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term ‘Monday morning fever’.
  • The illness usually has good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops.
  • It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxidefumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur.
  • The pathogenesis is not known, but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.
  • Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead antimony, silver and aluminium, etc.
  • Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Zinc toxicity resembles malarial chills.

questions.text: Which of the following principles governs biomedical research in human subjects?
questions.solution:
Helsinki declaration governs biomedical research in human subjects.

  • The Declaration of Helsinki (DoH) is a set of ethical principles regarding human experimentation developed for the medical community by the World Medical Association (WMA). It is widely regarded as the cornerstone document on human research ethics.
  • It is not a legally binding instrument under the international law, but instead draws its authority from the degree to which it has been codified in, or influenced, national or regional legislation and regulations.
  • Its role was described by a Brazilian forum in 2000 in these words "Even though the Declaration of Helsinki is the responsibility of the World Medical Association, the document should be considered the property of all humanity".

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with sudden weakness in his left leg. He no past medical history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, or hypertension, and no family history of myocardial infarction or stroke. Physical examination reveals a motor weakness in the left leg, with no other neurologic deficits, and no cardiac murmur. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain demonstrates a small ischemic infarct in the arterial distribution of the brain correlating with motor control of the left leg.  Angiography and echocardiography revealed normal coronary arteries, normal valves with no vegetations, and a small right-to-left shunt. Which of the following is most likely associated with this scenario?
questions.solution:
• The above case is of paradoxical embolism, also called a crossed embolism, which refers to an embolus which is carried from the venous side of circulation to the arterial side. This occurs by way of a right-to-left shunt.
  • Ordinarily, atrial septal defects result in a left-to-right shunt across the atrial septum, but over time may develop into a right to left shunt (Eisenmenger Syndrome).
  • The likelihood of right-to-left passage of an embolus is often enhanced by pulmonary hypertension, sometimes secondary to pulmonary thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby girl had normal growth and development for the first few months, but then progressively deteriorated with deafness, blindness, atrophied muscle, inability to swallow, and seizures. Early on in the diagnosis of the child, it was noticed that a cherry red macula was present in both eyes. Considering the child in the above case, measurement of which one of the following would enable one to determine whether the mutation were in the hex A or hex B gene?
questions.solution:
The measurement of globoside would help to determine whether the mutation is in hex A or hex B gene, as in hex A gene mutation the globoside levels are normal while in hex B mutation the globosides level is increased.

  • The presence of cherry red macula and other symptoms is suggestive that the child has either Tay–Sachs or Sandhoff’s disease, both of which are sphingolipidoses (lipid storage diseases) that are a group of inherited diseases that are caused by a genetic defect in the catabolism of lipids containing sphingosine.
  • The hex A gene codes for hexosaminidase A, whereas the hex B gene codes for hexosaminidase B.
  • The hex A protein consists of two A and two B subunits, and cleaves only GM2. The hex B protein is a B tetramer, and cleaves both GM2 and globoside.
  • Tay–Sachs disease, is associated with loss of hex A activity. The globoside degradation is normal as the hex B protein is normal.
  • The loss of hex B activity and globoside will accumulate in Sandhoff’s disease, but not in Tay–Sachs disease.
  • Note that the GM2 will accumulate in both hexA and hexB gene mutations.

questions.text: Which among the following layer has abundant desmosomes ?
questions.solution:
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes.

The image showing layers of the epidermis, it is divided from deep to superficial as 

  • Stratum basale (Basal layer)
  • Stratum spinosum (Spinous or prickle cell layer)
  • Stratum granulosum (Granular layer)
  • Stratum lucidum (Clear layer)
  • Stratum corneum (Cornified layer)

Stratum spinosum- contain several layers of closely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with each other by means of numerous cell surface projections. These cells are anchored to each other by desmosomes that provide tensile strength and cohesion to the layer. when the skin is seen under light microscopy, the cell tend to shrink away except where they are joined by desmosomes, giving them spiny appearance. 

 

Desmosomes:

They are the major intercellular junctions in the skin which join the adjacent keratinocytes.

They contain 3 proteins inside called as Desmoglein(dsg), Desmocollin and Desmoplakin.

Destruction Disease
Desmoglein IgG pemphigus
Staphylococcal scladed skin syndrome
Bullous impetigo
Desmocollin

IgA pemphigus
Desmoplakin

Paraneoplastic pemphigus

Note: If the question was asked about the location of Hemi-desmosomes, then the answer will be : Between stratum basale and dermo-epidermal junction.

questions.text: Extra embryonic mesoderm is derived from ____.
questions.solution:
Extra embryonic mesoderm is formed from primary yolk sac.

Extrembryonic mesoderm :

  • A new population of cells appears between inner surface of cytotrophoblast and outer surface of exocoelomic cavity. These cells, derived from primary yolk sac cells, form a fine loose connective tissue called extraembryonic mesoderm, which eventually fills all the space between trophoblast externally and amnion and extracoelomic membrane internally.
  • Large cavities develop in extraembryonic mesoderm , which become confluent, they from a new space known as extrembryonic coelom or chorionic cavity .
  • Extrembryonic mesoderm lining the cytotrophoblast and amnion is called extraembryonic somatopleuric mesoderm , lining covering the yolk sac is exytraembryonic splanchanopleuric mesoderm.

questions.text: Lower two parts of sternal body is fused by
questions.solution:
The four middle pieces of sternum  fuse with one another from below upwards between 14 - 25 years .

Sternum development and ossification:

  • It develops by fusion of two sternal plates formed on either side of midline.
  • ossification centres for Manubrium , 1st and 2nd sternebrae apper in 5th foetal month. 3rd and 4th appear in 5th and 6th months. 
  • These fuse below upwards during puberty and fusion complete by 25 years .

Note :

  • centre for xiphoid appear during third year and fuses with body by 40 years.
  • manubrium unites body 60years.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents to the ortho OPD  with the following deformity. Which of the following sentence is true regarding the fracture causing this deformity?

choices.text: Milch classification is used to classify this fracture
Ulnar nerve is the most common nerve to be involved in this fracture
Three point bony relationship is maintained on clinical examination of the fracture
Non union is the most common complication leading to Gun stock deformity

questions.solution:
The above image shows the “Gun stock” deformity which occurs due to malunion following Supracondylar fracture of humerus.(Not non union)

Three point bony relationship is maintained in Supracondylar fracture.

Three point bony landmarks in the elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

 

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-8 years.
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture: Extension type>Flexion type.
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension.
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures.

Characteristic displacements in Supracondylar fracture(Mnemonic: MID)

  • M- Medial rotation/medial tilt.
  • I-Impaction(proximal shift).
  • D- Dorsal displacement/dorsal tilt.

Nerve injury

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type: Ulnar nerve.

Vessel injury

  • Most common vessel to be injured: Brachial artery.

On examination:

  • Unusual posterior prominence of tip of the olecranon.
  • Three point bony relationship is maintained with respect to each other but not concerning the shaft of the humerus.

Complications:

  • Malunion (Most common): Posteromedially displaced fractures  tend to develop Cubitus Varus (Gunstock deformity)
  • Nerve injury: usually neuropraxia, hence transient.
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome(The most common fracture to cause this in children)
  • Non-union is unknown.

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture

  • Closed reduction and K-wire fixation.
  • Tractions used: Dunlop and Smith's.

Treatment of Cubitus Varus deformity

  • Lateral closed wedge osteotomy- French
  • Medial open wedge osteotomy-King's

questions.text: Replacing glutamate by which amino acid, will not increase  the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
The valine doesnt increase UV absorption at 280nm.

The amino acids which absorb 250-290nm (maximum at 280nm) UV light are

  • Tryptophan (Maximum Absorption)
  • Tyrosine
  • Phenylalanine

questions.text: Urea and Kreb's cycle are linked by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Urea and Kreb's cycle are linked by Fumarate.

The ammonia from all over the body reaches the liver and is detoxified to urea (major end product of protein catabolism) by liver cells and excreted by the kidney, it partly takes place in mitochondria and partly in cytoplasm.

The products of the urea cycle obtained by cleavage of argininosuccinate are arginine and fumarate by the enzyme arginosuccinate lyase, this fumarate enters the Kreb's cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle) to get finally converted to oxaloacetate, hence also referred to as the urea bicycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the X-ray depicted below?

choices.text: Most common site of this lesion is distal femur
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
The closest differential diagnosis of this lesion is Aneurysmal Bone Cyst
Non ossifying fibroma is a variant of this lesion

questions.solution:
Osteoclast giant cells do not constitute the proliferative component of the tumor whereas neoplastic cells of giant cell tumor are primitive osteoblast precursors but they represent only a minority of the tumor cells.

The X-ray depicts Giant cell tumor (GCT) which can be identified by the following points:

  • Epiphyseal tumor(next to the joint surface) and extending to the metaphyseal region.
  • Characteristic "soap bubble appearance" with free septations.
  • Eccentrically located lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones which frequently breaks through the cortex.

Option A:Most common site of GCT/osteoclastoma is distal femur > proximal tibia.

Option B: Mononuclear cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor. (Not giant cells)

Option C: Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is the closest differential of GCT and can be differentiated as follows.

  GCT ABC
Age After skeletal maturity Before skeletal maturity
Region Epiphyseal tumor extending to the metaphyseal region Metaphyseal tumor extending to the epiphyseal region rarely
Radiological appearance Soap bubble appearance-free septations

Air fluid levels- irregular septations seperating blood filled sinuses (seen on MRI) 
Bones affected Lower end of femur > Upper end of tibia > Lower end of radius (Characteristic)

Tibia

Option D:Giant cell variants

  • Aneurysmal bone cyst (closest)
  • Non ossifyong fibroma(commonest)
  • Osteoblastoma and Osteosacroma
  • Chondromyxoid fibroma and Chondroblastoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Brown tumor of hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: 4 molecules of NH3 are the by-products formed in a reaction in the synthesis of heme. The enzyme catalysing this specific step is ___.
questions.solution:
4 molecules of NH3 are the by product formed in a reaction catalysed by Hydroxymethylbilane synthase in synthesis of heme.

Heme synthesis : Synthesised in almost all parts of the body except in mature erythrocytes. 

                            Partly cytoplasmic and partly mitochondrial.

4 important steps :

1- Synthesis of porphobilinogen ( Monopyrole )- by ALA dehydratase.

2- Synthesis of uroporphyrinogen ( tetrapyrole by 4 molecule of porphobilinogen) -by hydroxymethylbilane synthase.

3- Conversion of uroporphyrinogen to protophorphyrin.

4- Formation of heme by incorporation of iron.

In rection catalysed by hydroxymethylbilane synthase four molecules of porphobilinogen combine to from hydroxymethylbilane giving 4 molecules of NH3.

questions.text: A couple brings their 1 year old male child Pappu to OPD, complaining of high grade fever and pain in the right hip . On examination, there is  tenderness in Scarpa's triangle, swelling in the right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip, absent movements in right hip region is noted. X ray reveals  mild increase in medial joint space. Which of the following is not true regarding the diagnosis ?

choices.text: Morrey's criterion is used for diagnosis
It is the most common cause of bony ankylosis
A recent history of upper respiratory tract, of viral origin is usually present
The next line of management is USG guided aspiration of hip

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the clinical condition mentioned is Septic arthritis.

Here, the child is having high grade fever (toxic child) with swollen hip and tenderness in the hip joint. There is also flexion abduction and external rotation of the hip which makes the examiner to think of either Transient synovitis or septic arthritis. To narrow down the differential diagnoses among two, the movement of the hip joint is a clue yielding. Here there is absence of hip joint movements which points the diagnosis as Septic arthritis of the hip.(Transient synovitis has mild reduction of joint movements and not "absent movements").

A recent history of upper respiratory tract, of viral origin is usually present in Transient synovitis, whereas hematogenous route of infection occurs in Septic arthritis. S.Aureus is the most common organism.

Option A: Morrey's criterion is used for diagnosing septic arthritis.

  • >38.3 degree celsius temperature.
  • Swelling of suspected joint.
  • Pain in the joint that increases with movements.
  • Systemic symptoms.
  • No other pathological process.
  • Satisfactory resoponse to antibiotic therapy.

Option B: 

Fibrous ankylosis Bony ankylosis
Some movement possible No movement possible
Painful movements Painless joint
Most common cause: TB arthritis of hip and knee Most common cause: Septic arthritis > Pott's spine

Option D: USG guided aspiration helps to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and also helps to differentiate from transient synovitis.

The order of investigation in any inflammatory joint swelling is Xray > MRI > Aspiration

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rates
At equilibrium, the reaction rates  of the forward and back reactions are equal
At equilibrium, the rate of conversion of substrates to products therefore equals the rate at which products are converted to substrates

questions.solution:
The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rate constants (not the reaction rates).

  • At equilibrium, the reaction rates (not the rate constants) of the forward and back reactions are equal.
  • Equilibrium is a dynamic state. Although there is no net change in the concentration of substrates or products, individual substrate and product molecules are continually being interconverted.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker of bone formation?

choices.text: N and C terminal propeptide of type I procollagen
Cross linked N and C terminal telopeptide

questions.solution:
Cross-linked N and C terminal telopeptides are markers of bone resorption.

Markers of bone formation

  • Serum bone-specific alkaline phosphatase
  • Serum osteocalcin
  • Serum propeptide of type I procollagen

Markers of bone resorption

  • Urine and serum cross-linked N-telopeptide
  • Urine and serum cross-linked C-telopeptide
  • Urine Pyridinium crosslinks (pyridinoline - PYD, deoxypyridinoline -DPD)

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS)?
questions.solution:
The most common MPS is Sanfilippo (MPS III), followed by Hurler and Hunter’s.

Sanfilippo disease makes up a genetically heterogeneous but clinically similar group of 4 recognized types.

  • The enzyme deficient is involved in Heparan sulfate
  • Onset of symptoms: between 2 and 6 years of age.
  • It is characterized by severe CNS involvement with a mild somatic involvement, this disproportionate involvement of CNS is a unique feature of MPS III.
  • Other features include sleep disturbances, aggressive behavior problems, hirsutism.
  • Stem cell therapy is not beneficial and no enzyme replacement therapy is useful.

Note: corneal clouding is absent in Hunters and Sanfilippo.

questions.solution:
The limb of the patient is seen lying in a Flexed, ADducted and slightly Internally Rotated posture(FADIR), classically seen in posterior hip dislocation.

Hip dislocation can be classified into:

Anterior Central  Posterior
Attitude of limb:Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation Head is felt Per-Rectal Attitude of limb:Flexion,  Adduction, Internal rotation

questions.text: The lack of alpha oxidation of fatty acid leads to which of the following?

choices.text: Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
The lack of alpha oxidation of fatty acid leads to accumulation of phytanic acid.

Alpha oxidation is the removal of one carbon atom at a time from alpha carbon atom. Here the fatty acid does not need activation unlike beta oxidation. It occurs in branched chain fatty acid to remove methyl group at branch points. It neither consumes nor generate energy. Oxidation of phytanic acid is by alpha oxidation , phytanic acid is major dietary methylated fatty acid seen in dairy products.

Defect in alpha oxidation of phytanic acid in peroxisomes is called refsum's disease, the deficient enzyme is phytanoyl-CoA dioxygenase.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of events in Southern blotting?

choices.text: Separation of DNA fragments by electrophoresis followed by transfer to a membrane and then hybridization with a labelled probe sequence.
Hybridization of DNA fragments with a labelled probe sequence followed by separation by electrophoresis and then transfer to a membrane.
Separationof DNA fragments with a labelled probe sequence followed by separation by electrophoresis and then transfer to a membrane.
Transfer of DNA fragments to a membrane followed by separation by electrophoresis and then hybridization with a labelled probe sequence.

questions.solution:
Steps in Southern blotting:

  • DNA fragments are first separated by electrophoresis.
  • The DNA in the gel is then made single stranded by exposure to dilute alkali, and transferred by capillary action to the nylon membrane, which is laid over it.
  • The relative positions of the different DNA fragments are thus preserved on the membrane.
  • The membrane is then soaked in buffer containing the labelled probe, which base pairs with the DNA fragment of interest.
  • The position of that fragment is then determined by autoradiographic (exposure of the membrane to X-ray film), or fluorescent detection of the hybridized probe.

questions.text: Which enzyme interconverts  Adenine Nucleotides?
questions.solution:
Adenylate Kinase (Myokinase) interconverts Adenine Nucleotides.

Adenylate kinase is important for the maintenance of energy homeostasis in cells because it allows:

  • High-energy phosphate in ADP to be used in the synthesis of ATP.
  • The AMP formed as a consequence of activating reactions involving ATP to rephosphorylated to ADP.
  • AMP to increase in concentration when ATP becomes depleted so that it is able to act as a metabolic (allosteric) signal to increase the rate of catabolic reactions, which in turn lead to the generation of more ATP.

questions.text: The fracture seen in the X-ray given below is?
questions.solution:
The image shows an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. So the fracture seen in the X-ray is Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. The most common clinical feature is tenderness over the distal end of the forearm. 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Other options: 

Option B: Monteggia fracture is the fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of the proximal radio-ulnar joint and the subluxation of the radiocapitellar joint.

Option C: Smith's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment. It also known as reverse Colle's fracture.

Option D: Colle's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever, along with painful sores in the mouth and small, tense vescicles with surrounding erythema on the palms and soles in a child point towards the diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease. The most common cause of which worldwide is coxackievirus A16. 

Spread is by droplets or faecal contamination and the incubation period is 7 days. The fever is generally mild, and is followed by the appearance of lesions. The characteristic lesions are slightly oval, with a grey blister roof and a narrow rim of erythema. The oral lesions are aphthoid and are less painful than aphthous ulcers.

Only symptomatic treatment is given. The lesions generally disappear in 7 - 10 days.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Points in favor:

  • 40-year female
  • Painful blisters over oral mucosa and genitalia
  • Suprabasal split 
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Here there will be extremely pruritic vesicular eruptions over extensors.

Immunofluorescence shows Granular IgA deposits along with the dermal papillae.

Option C: Bullous pemphigoid

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • No mucosal involvement (unlike pemphigus vulgaris).
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • No mucosal involvement.
  • Subcorneal blisters are seen.
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg1.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2

  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A 60 kg adult male has a haematocrit reading of 40% and a plasma volume of 3L. What is his total blood volume in L?
questions.solution:
His total blood volume is 5 litres.

Calculation:

Hematocrit is a percentage, as it is 40% which equals 40/100= 0.4.

(Normally, Total blood volume is 8% of body weight).

questions.text: In a cutaneous sensory neuron, at which of the following places is the propagated action potential generated?
questions.solution:
In cutaneous sensory neurons, propagated action potentials are generated in the initial node of Ranvier.

From a functional point of view, neurons generally have four important zones :

  1. A receptor, or dendritic zone, where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated
  2. A site where propagated action potentials are generated (the initial segment in spinal motor neurons, the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons)
  3. An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings
  4. The nerve endings, where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters

The cell body is often located at the dendritic zone end of the axon, but it can be within the axon (eg, auditory neurons)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best plane for the measurement of volume of hippocampus?
questions.solution:
The best plane for measurement of the volume of the hippocampus is the coronal plane, angled perpendicular to the long axis of the hippocampus in MRI, which is represented by the image marked B.

Coronal MRI is taken perpendicular to the long axis of the temporal horn can be used to measure:

  • Volume of hippocampus - measured in Alzheimer's disease and medial temporal seizures
  • Medial temporal lobe atrophy (MTA)

The planes of MRI are given below.

Image marked as D shows the axial section of a CT.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

  • Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury
  • Verrucous growth
  • Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

 

  Chromoblastomycosis Sporotrichosis
Cause Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii
Presentation Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics
Histology Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies Asteroid bodies

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A person states to his psychiatrist, "I work for the Government and I am so important in my office that the other people will not be able to work without me". This is characteristic of
questions.solution:
The statement is characteristic of a narcissistic personality disorder.

A narcissistic personality disorder:

  • A sense of self-importance, grandiosity and preoccupied with fantasies of success.
  • The person beleives that he is special, requires excessive admiration.
  • Reacts with rage when criticized and interpersonally exploitative.

Option A: A histrionic personality disorder

  • Excitable, overtly emotional and behave in a dramatic way.
  • They want to be centre of attention and exaggerate everything, making it sound more important than really it is.

Option B: An antisocial personality disorder

  • They do not have regard for right of others and frequently violate them.

Option D: A borderline personality disorder

  • They have significant mood swings.
  • History of unstable relationships/ self destructive acts are frequently present.

questions.solution:
The features of abdominal distension , delayed development , corneal clouding and the following image showing , thickened calvaria , j shaped sella helps is diagnosis of hurlers syndrome.
