questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Revised Trauma Score ?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is not a component of Revised Trauma Score.

Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate and Systolic BP are components of Revised Trauma Score (0-12).

Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma are :

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: An intubated patient is on the ventilator in an ICU. An intern who is to calculate the GCS score recognizes that the patient opens eyes to verbal command and is able to withdraw when a painful stimulus is applied. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient in the above scenario is E3 VNT M4.

Analyzing the GCS score of the above patient,

  • Eye opening to verbal commands – 3
  • Verbal response – NT (NT stands for Not testable, as the patient is intubated)
  • Motor response – withdrawal to pain – 4

In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as ‘not testable,’ NT.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4

Motor Response Score

Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope following a blow to the distended bladder. Later on, as the pain subsided the abdomen began to distend. However, he had no desire to micturate. Which among the following is true regarding his condition?

choices.text: Extraperitoneal extravasation of urine is likely to be present
MRI is the ideal investigation to diagnose this condition
Repair is done using a 2/0 absorbable suture
Laparoscopic approach is unfavourable in this case

questions.solution:
The above scenario with a blow to a distended bladder causing sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope is a typical presentation of intraperitoneal bladder rupture. Repair is usually done by a laparotomy in which the edges of the bladder are sutured using a single-layer 2/0 absorbable suture. 

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection as below:

  1. If the bladder rupture is above the peritoneal reflection (on the bladder dome), the urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal.
  2. If the bladder rupture is below the peritoneal reflection and not on the dome, the urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or falls on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. There will be an associated increase in BUN and creatinine due to systemic absorption of the extravasated urine and it may also lead to chemical peritonitis.

Investigations :

CT is the ideal investigation for diagnosing bladder rupture. A plain erect X-ray may show a ground-glass appearance. Intravenous urography (IVU) may confirm a leak. Retrograde cystography will confirm the diagnosis. It is important to image the patient after drainage of contrast as the full bladder may mask extravasation.

Treatment : 

  • Extravesical injury– catheter drainage for 10 days
  • Intraperitoneal injury– laparotomy, repair, and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

questions.text: Thymoma with invasion into great vessels comes under which stage of Masaoka staging.
questions.solution:
Thymoma with invasion into great vessels comes under stage III of the Masaoka staging system.

Masaoka staging system for thymoma:

Stage

Features

Stage I

Encapsulated tumor with no gross or microscopic evidence of capsular invasion

Stage II

Gross capsular invasion or invasion into the mediastinal fat or pleura or microscopic capsular invasion

Stage III

Gross invasion into the pericardium, great vessels, or lung

Stage IVA

Pleural or pericardial dissemination

Stage IVB

Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis

questions.text: Which of these is the correct sequence of Maslow's hierarchy of needs ?

choices.text: Safety- Physiological needs- Self actualization- Belonging- Self esteem
Physiological needs- Safety- Belonging- Self esteem- Self actualization
Safety- Self actualization- Belonging- Physiological needs- Self esteem
Self actualization- Physiological needs- Safety- Belonging- Self esteem

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of Maslow's hierarchy of needs is physiological needs -> safety -> belonging -> self-esteem -> self-actualization.

Abraham Maslow proposed " A theory of human motivation" in which human needs are arranged according to hierarchy in a five-level pyramid.

He suggested that the higher needs can be fulfilled only once the lower needs are fulfilled. The ascending order of the needs is shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding schizophrenia ?

choices.text: Onset is most common in fourth decade
Severe depression is most common association
Cognitive deficits are present in the prodromal stage

questions.solution:
Cognitive deficits are present in the prodromal stage.

Option A: Onset is most common in fourth decade - False

The onset is usually in 2nd and 3rd decade.

Option B: Severe depression is most common association - False

The most common comorbidities in schizophrenia are substance use disorders and anxiety disorders.

DSM does not allow to diagnose major depressive episode in presence of schizophrenia, though its known that depressive symtoms are quite common and increase the suicide risk. Given that DSM-5, doesn't even include depression in the list of comorbidities in schizophrenia.

Option D: Shows characteristic changes on EEG - False

No consistent EEG changes have been found in schizophrenia.

questions.text: The following capnographic tracing is seen in?
questions.solution:
The image shows a "pigtail" capnogram which occurs due to the sudden spike of expired CO2  caused by sudden airway closure.

It is typically seen in poor lung compliance, pregnant women and obese patients.

It occurs when a poorly compliant lung secondary to pregnancy squeezes the last few mL of CO2 rich gas from the alveoli.

Subsequently, the collapse of the lung parenchyma occludes the small bronchi and puts an end to the escape of gas.

 

Endobronchial intubation:

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: You notice the resident performing Pre-oxygenation before induction,  in a patient with an adequate respiratory drive. He would be performing the preoxygenation for how much time?
questions.solution:
Pre-oxygenation (Denitrogenation) before induction should be given for 3 minutes.

The aim of pre-oxygenation before induction is to improve the oxygen reservoir of the lungs by replacing Nitrogen with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes.

In case of emergency conditions where affording 3 minutes is life-threatening, then, the patient is asked to take 4-5 deep breaths with 100% oxygen as an alternative.

questions.text: All are components of Basic Life Support (BLS), except:
questions.solution:
Needle cricothyrotomy is not a component of BLS. It is a component of Advanced Life Support (ALS).

Components of BLS:

  • Airway - Manual
  • Breathing - Bag and Mask
  • Circulation - Cardiac massage
  • Defibrillation - Automated External Defibrillator/Public access Defibrillator

Related Pearl: Neurocutaneous syndomes

Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: VHL gene, tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Conditions associated with it include:
    • Renal cell carcinoma
    • Hemangioblastomas
    • Pheochromocytomas
    • Angiomatosis
    • Cysts in the pancreas, liver, and kidneys

Neurofibromatosis type 1: 

  • Also known as Von Recklinghausen Disease
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF1 gene on chromosome 17, codes for the Neurofibromin protein
  • Features of NF 1:  “CAFE SPOTS”
    • Café-au-lait spots (multiple, >6, >5 mm in children or >15 mm in adults)
    • Axillary or inguinal freckling
    • Family history (autosomal dominant inheritance)
    • Eye findings (Lisch nodules on the iris)
    • Skin neurofibromas (benign tumors)
    • Plexiform neurofibromas (larger, deeper tumors)
    • Optic pathway gliomas (tumors of the optic nerve)
    • Tibial dysplasia (bone abnormalities, e.g., bowing of the tibia)
    • Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis)

Neurofibromatosis type 2:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that codes for the Merlin protein
  • Features: "MISME"
    • Multiple schwannomas (bilateral vestibular schwannomas are hallmark)
    • Intracranial meningiomas
    • Spinal tumors (ependymomas, schwannomas)
    • Meningiomas (intracranial or spinal)
    • Ependymomas (spinal cord tumors)

Tuberous sclerosis: 

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Mutation in the TSC 1 gene on chromosome 9 and TSC 2 on chromosome 16
  • Features: “HAMARTOMAS”
    • Hamartomas in skin and CNS
    • Ash-leaf spots (Hypopigmented macules)
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Rhabdomyomas of the heart
    • Tuberous sclerosis
    • Autosomal dOMinant
    • Angiomyolipomas
    • Seizures and shagreen patches
    • Also associated with intellectual disability

Sturge Weber Syndrome

  • Also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis
  • Somatic mosaicism due to mutation in GNAQ gene
  • Features: “STURGE - I”
    • Portwine Stain (Nevus flammeus)
    • Tram track calcifications (leptomeningeal angioma)
    • Unilateral weakness
    • Retinal detachment and atrophy
    • Glaucoma
    • Epilepsy
    • Intellectual disability

questions.text: Balanced resuscitation means

choices.text: Simultaneous management of Airway, Breathing, Circulation
Use of equal amount of Crystalloids and Colloids
Restrictive use of fluids and blood products

questions.solution:
Balanced resuscitation means restrictive use of fluids and blood products.

Balanced resuscitation has 2 components:

  • Hypotensive resuscitation
    • Here, the resuscitation of hemorrhagic shock is done using fluids in such a way that the blood pressure is not targeted to reach the normal. (The target Systolic BP here is 80-100mmHg) The reason being, if the pressure is increased suddenly, then the tamponade effect of hemorrhage is lost due to dislodgement of blood clots and increase in blood pressure will lead to further bleeding.
  • Hemostatic resuscitation
    • Provides resuscitation with blood components resembling whole blood with the aims of maintaining circulating volume, limiting ongoing bleeding, and preventing the lethal triad of hypothermia, acidosis and acute coagulopathy of trauma.
    • Involves blood component ratios of 1 RBC: 1 FFP: 1 Platelets

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady, G3P2 with 10 weeks intrauterine gestation comes to OPD with an Intra Uterine Contraceptive Device(IUCD) and the tail of the IUCD is noted to be protruding from the cervical os. The most appropriate course of action is?

choices.text: Keep the IUCD in place and continue prophylactic antibiotics
Keep the IUCD in place without any treatment
Remove the IUCD immediately and continue pregnancy
Terminate the pregnancy because of high risk of infection

questions.solution:
The most appropriate course of action in this patient at 10 weeks intrauterine gestation is to Remove the IUCD immediately and continue pregnancy.

Intrauterine Devices in Pregnancy

  • If IUD strings are visible and  the pregnancy is less than 13 weeks, the IUD should be removed as soon as possible to prevent later septic abortion, premature rupture of the membranes, and premature birth .
  • When the strings of the IUD are not visible, an ultrasound examination should be performed to localize the IUD and determine whether expulsion has occurred. If the IUD is present, there are three options for management:
    • Therapeutic abortion .
    • Ultrasound-guided intrauterine removal of the IUD.
    • Continuation of the pregnancy with the device left in place

Note : 

If the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy, ultrasound evaluation of the location of the IUD should be considered .

  • If the IUD is not in a fundal location, ultrasound-guided removal using small alligator forceps may be successful.
  • If the location is fundal, the IUD should be left in place. When pregnancy continues with an IUD in place, the patient must be warned of the symptoms of intrauterine infection and should be cautioned to seek care promptly for fever or flulike symptoms, abdominal cramping, or bleeding. At the earliest sign of infection, high-dose intravenous antibiotic therapy should be given and the pregnancy evacuated promptly.

questions.text: A 22 year old newly married women consults you because of painful coitus, with the pain located at the vaginal introitus. It is accompanied by painful involuntary contraction of the pelvic muscles. The pelvic examination appears to be normal. Of the following, which is the most common cause ?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginismus, defined as involuntary spasm of the pelvis muscles and vaginal outlet. It is usually psychogenic.

It should be differentiated with frigidity(lack of sexual desire) and dyspareunia(pain/discomfort associated with sexual activity).

Dyspareunia is frequently associated with pelvic pathology such as endometriosis, pelvic adhesions or ovarian neoplasms.

The pain of vaginismus may be psychogenic in origin or due to pelvic pathology such as adhesions, endometriosis, leiomyomas.

Treatment of vaginismus is primarily pyschotherapeutic, as organic vulvar or pelvic cause(such as atrophy, Bartholin's gland cyst or abscess) is very rare.

questions.text: A test for hepatic carcinoma  is performed on 500 patients with biopsy-proven disease and 300 patients free of the disease. The test shows positive results on 350 patients with the disease and negative results on 150 patients without the disease. Which of the following is false regarding the test ?
questions.solution:
Specificity in the given test is 50%.

The table for the above test is as given below :

  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive 350(a) 150(b)
Test negative 150(c) 150(d)

 

  •  Sensitivity = a/a+c = 350/500 = 70%
  •  Specificity = d/d+b = 150/300 = 50%
  •  PPV = a/a+b = 350 / 500 =70%
  •  NPV = d/d+c = 150 / 300 = 50%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Ball's operation is done for Pruritis Vulvae.

Ball's operation rarely performed now consists of division of cutaneous nerves by a circular incision around the vulva.

The effect lasts for 3-6 months.

questions.text: In a population of 100, prevalence of candida glabrata was found to be 80%. If the investigator has to repeat the prevalence with 95% confidence, what will the prevalence be?
questions.solution:
Confidence intervals(CI) for population proportion (95% confidence).

CI = p +/- 2 x SEP

Where, SEP (sample error of proportion) =√pq/n

Hence,

In the given question :

  • p (prevalence) = 0.80 (80%) 
  • q = 1-p = 1-0.80= 0.20
  • n (sample size) = 100

questions.text: Identify the instrument seen in the picture
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is Episiotomy scissor.

  • It has angulation in the scissor.
  • Angulation in the scissor prevents extension of pelvic tears in to the anal margins, obstetric anal aphincter injuries and complete perineal tear.

questions.text: What is the fixative used in Pap Smear ?
questions.solution:
95% ethyl alcohol is used as a fixative.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test

  • It is a screening test only.
  • A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • Ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test.

Procedure

  • The patient is put in dorsal position & labia parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slide.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

NOTE: Use of ether as a fixative has been discontinued as a part of standard practice from the year 1954. Ref: https://www.karger.com/Article/PDF/457827

The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. Historically ether was used along with alcohol as a fixative for pap smear. For further reading on the development of Pap smear technique refer https://www.karger.com/Article/PDF/457827

questions.text: The P value of a randomized controlled trial comparing operation X which is a new procedure and operation Y which is gold standard procedure is 0.04, the conclusion from the following is

choices.text: The investigator can be 96% sure that the result is obtained by chance.
The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation X is better than operation Y,  when in truth it is not is 4%
Type II error is small and we can accept the findings of this study
The power of the study to detect a difference between operation X & Y is 96%

questions.solution:
The P value of this randomized control trial is comparing operation X and Y (gold standard) is 0.04, thus the probability of commiting type I error is 4%, means that there is a 4% chance that the conclusion that operation X is better than operation Y when in truth it is not. 

 

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A group of cardiologists found a correlation coefficient of 0.90  (p-value = 0.01) between the systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels of patients attending their clinics. Which of the following statements is an incorrect interpretation of this study?

choices.text: The magnitude of systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels are closely related
A patient with a high systolic BP is likely to have high serum cholesterol
A patient with a low systolic BP is likely to have low serum cholesterol
80% of the variation in BP can be explained by serum cholesterol and vice versa

questions.solution:
Correlation is an indicator of the strength and direction of the relationship between 2 variables, not the magnitude.

The given study is statistically significant (p-value = 0.01) with a strong positive correlation (r = +0.90) between systolic BP and cholesterol levels. Thus, it is likely that patients with high systolic BP will have high cholesterol levels and those with low BP will have low cholesterol levels.

The coefficient of determination (r2)here is 0.9 x 0.9 = 0.81. This indicates that around 80% of the variation in systolic BP among the patients can be explained by serum cholesterol levels.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is
questions.solution:
The following image shows bacterial growth curve, characterized by an initial lag phase, followed by log phase or exponential growth phase, then reaching a stationary phase followed by phase of decline.

  • A - Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence by the end of lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained
  • B - Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time
  • C - Stationary phase: The viable count remains stationary as an equilibrium exists between the dying and the newly formed cells.
  • D - Phase of decline: Cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death.

questions.text: For effective protection after unprotected intercourse , one single tab of Levonorgestrel 0.75mg  has already been taken. When should the next dose be taken ?
questions.solution:
For emergency contraception levonorgestrel is used, 0.75 mg initially, followed by another 0.75mg 12 hour later.

Emergency(Post coital) contraceptives:

  • It can be started upto 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse but greatest  protection occurs if it is given within 72 hours of unprotected sex.
  • Levonorgestrel 1.5mg single dose is the method of choice.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Prevents ovulation
  • Prevents fertilization
  • Prevents implanatation by affecting endometrial lining.

Methods of Emergency contraception

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and after 12 hours
Etinyl estradiol 50μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tab stat and 2 tab after 12 hours
Conjugated estrogen 15mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUD's

Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.

Not suitable for rape victims
Centchroman 2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval  of 12 hours within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal 30 mg within 72 hours

questions.text: Which of the following describes the theme of World health day 2018?

choices.text: From farm to plate, make food safe

questions.solution:
The theme of World health day 2018 as well as 2019 is Universal health coverage: everyone, everywhere.

World Health Day 2021: Build a fairer, healthier world for everyone, everywhere.

World health day 2020: Support nurses and midwives

World health day 2017: Depression: Let's talk

World health day 2016: Halt the rise, beat diabetes

World health day 2015: From farm to plate, make food safe

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding "Menstrual Hygiene scheme "?

choices.text: It includes only adolescent girls between 10-19 years
Sanitary napkin pads are branded as "Free days"
Sanitary pads are given free of cost to all menstruating females
ASHA worker will be responsible for distribution of sanitary pads

questions.solution:
The sanitary napkins packs for provision to rural adolescent girls are given at a subsidized rate of Rs 6 for a pack of 6  napkins. The scheme applies only to rural adoloscent girls and they will be the beneficiaries. (Not all menstruating females)

  • The scheme was initially implemented in 2011 in 107 selected districts in 17 States wherein a pack of six sanitary napkins called “Freedays” was provided to rural adolescent girls for Rs. 6.
  • From 2014 onwards, funds are now being provided to States/UTs under National Health Mission for decentralized procurement of sanitary napkins packs for provision to rural adolescent girls at a subsidized rate of Rs 6 for a pack of 6 napkins.
  • The ASHA will continue to be responsible for distribution, receiving an incentive @ Rs 1 per pack sold and a free pack of napkins every month for her own personal use.

questions.text: Which of the following is false  regarding "The National Programme for Prevention and Management of Burn Injuries"(NPPMBI) ?

choices.text: A burn unit should comprise of 4 beds
The programme was started in the 12th five year plan
Research for assessing behavioral, social and other determinants of burn Injuries is a component of the programme
The District Hospital component of the programme will be implemented through National Health Mission

questions.solution:
A Burn Unit should comprise of 6 beds (4 general beds + 2 Acute Care beds + Other Facilities required) according to NPPMBI.

The programme was started in the 12th five year plan.

Objectives:

  • To reduce incidence,  mortality, morbidity and disability due to Burn Injuries
  • To improve awareness among the general masses and vulnerable groups especially the women, children, industrial and hazardous occupational workers.
  • To establish adequate infrastructural facility and network for Behavior change communication, burn management and rehabilitation interventions.
  • To carry out Research for assessing behavioral, social and other determinants of Burn Injuries in our country for effective need based program planning for Burn Injuries, monitoring and subsequent evaluation.

Components:

  • Prevention Programme (IEC)
  • Treatment
  • Rehabilitation
  • Training
  • Monitoring and Evaluation
  • Research

The programme falls within the overall ambit of centrally assisted scheme, namely, “Human resource in Health and Medical Education”. As per the financial norms of this umbrella scheme, the financial assistance during the 12th FYP will be shared between Central and State Government in a ratio of 75:25

The District Hospital component of the programme will be implemented through NHM

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about severe combined immunodeficiency disorders?

choices.text: They are inherited in both X linked and autosomal recessive mode.
Reticular dysgenesis of de Vaal is a mild form of combined immunodeficiency
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency
Swiss type agammaglobulinemia is associated with lymphocytopenia and severe defect in CMI

questions.solution:
Reticular dysgenesis of de vaal is the most serious form of combined immunodeficiency. Here the defect is at the level of the multipotent haemopoeitic stem cell.

Severe combined immunodeficiency disorders are associated with severe deficiency of both humoral and CMI.

  • They are inherited in both X-linked and autosomal recessive mode.
  • Reticular dysgenesis of de vaal is the most serious form of combined immunodeficiency. Here the defect is at the level of the multipotent haemopoeitic stem cell.
  • Swiss type agammaglobulinemia is associated with lymphocytopenia and severe defect in CMI. The basic defect is at the level of the lymphoid stem cell.
  • Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency. The condition is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities which can be discerned radiologically.

questions.text: Which of the following gives the result as shown in the image(5) below?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a positive slide coagulase test which is seen with Staphylococcus aureus.
Coagulase test is used to differentiate Staphylococcus aureus (positive) from coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CONS).
Coagulase is an enzyme produced by S. aureus that converts soluble fibrinogen in plasma to insoluble fibrin. 
 
Staphylococcus aureus produces two forms of coagulase, bound and free.
 
Slide coagulase test is done to detect bound coagulase or clumping factor and does not require coagulase-reacting factor (CRF) in plasma. 

Tube coagulase test is done to detect free coagulase and requires coagulase-reacting factor (CRF)in plasma.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding "Intensified Mission Indradhanush" ?

choices.text: It is for urban slums with migratory population
It includes vaccination against 12 vaccine preventable diseases
It ensures full immunization to more than 90% by December 2018
It reaches to children under 5 years of age

questions.solution:
Intensified Mission Indradhanush(IMI) aims to reach each and every child under two years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunisation programme.

12 vaccines of Mission indradhanush:

  • Seven vaccines were included in it previously (Diphtheria, Whooping cough, Tetanus, Poliomyelitis, Tuberculosis, Measles, and Hepatitis B. Hemophilus influenza is given in some states)
  • In 2016 four new vaccines were added (Japanese B Encephalitis, Rubella, Rotavirus, Injectable polio vaccine).
  • In 2017 pneumonia was added to the mission by incorporating pneumococcal conjugate vaccine into the universal immunization programme.

The special drive will focus on improving immunization coverage in select districts and cities to ensure full immunization to more than 90% by December 2018. The achievement of full immunization under Mission Indradhanush to at least 90% coverage was to be achieved by 2020 earlier. With the launch of IMI, the achievement of the target has now been advanced. 

 

IMI is for:

  • Urban slums with a migratory population
  • Nomadic sites
  • Areas with low immunization coverage identified through measles outbreak, cases of diphtheria and neonatal tetanus in the last 2 years.

Remember Intensified Mission Indradhanush:7 working days in a month, starting on 7th of every month, excluding Sundays, holidays and immunization days.

questions.text: Which of the following is  False about the Alkaline-encrusted cystitis?

choices.text: Corynebacterium jekeium is the etiological agent.
Associated with deposition of magnesium ammonium sulphate
It is a severe form of urinary tract infection (UTI).

questions.solution:
Corynebacterium urealyticum is the etiologic agent of Alkaline-encrusted cystitis.

  • C.urealyticum is a urease positive nondiphtherial Corynebacterium & an opportunistic pathogen.
  • Alkaline-crusted cystitis is a chronic inflammatory bladder infection associated with deposition of magnesium ammonium sulphate on the surface & walls of ulcerative lesions in the bladder.
  • It is a form of severe urinary tract infection (UTI).

Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

The mosquito as a vector:

  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: The following statements are false regarding botulism except:

choices.text: Clostridium botulinum toxins A,B,C,D,E and F cause human disease
Infant botulism is caused by ingestion of preformed toxin
Type A is associated with sudden death

questions.solution:
Strains of other clostridia species such as C. butyricum and C. Baratti are found to cause botulism.

Other options:

A:  Clostridium Botulinum Toxin types A, B, E, and (rarely) F cause disease in humans. Type C and D cause disease in animals(Type C,D- are bacteriophage coded)

B: Infant botulism occurs due to ingestion of spores, toxin is released inside the body. Whereas food borne botulism occurs due to preformed toxin mixed with canned food.

D: Type G has been associated with sudden death, but not with neuroparalytic illness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ESI Act?

choices.text: State government covers 1/8th and ESI corporation covers 7/8th of the cost of medical care
Maternity benefit is payable at full wages for upto 24 weeks
It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.18,000/- per month

questions.solution:
The state government's share of expenditure on medical care is 1/8th, and the ESI corporation's share of expenditure on medical care is 7/8th of the total cost.

Few important points about the ESI Act:

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • The employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill.
  • An employee contributes 0.75% of wages.
  • State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.
  • Medical benefit: Full medical care
  • Sickness benefit: 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days.
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases.
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 7 days in case of vasectomy and up to 14 days in case of tubectomy.
  • Maternity benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration up to 26 weeks (confinement) or 6 weeks (miscarriage/MTP) or 4 weeks (sickness arising out of pregnancy).
  • Funeral expenses: Cash not exceeding Rs.15,000.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Supplementary nutrition provided under the PM POSHAN programme should satisfy

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + 1/2 of the total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + 1/2 of the total energy requirement
1/2 of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of the total energy requirement
1/2 of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of the total energy requirement

questions.solution:
Under the PM POSHAN scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement of children in schools.

Minimum number of feeding days is 250.

The PM POSHAN scheme is also called the School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Some other principles of the PM POSHAN scheme are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.
  • The cost of meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meals should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, for as long as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.
    Note: In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: True about the condition shown in the image below

choices.text: It describes a transient condition in newborns
The membrane usually peels off within the first 4 months of life
It is a autosomal dominant condition.
It is not a type of congenital icthyosis

questions.solution:
The image shows a neonate encased in a shiny parchment‐like membrane indicative of a collodion baby, which is a transient condition in newborns. 

Except for Harlequin Ichthyosis, most autosomal recessive Congenital Ichthyosis patients present at birth as ‘collodion babies’.

  • This membrane usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life.
  • Initially, the clinical presentation can be quite severe and often includes ectropion and everted lips of different degrees, this later clears.
  • Collodion babies look very much alike at birth, but later take different clinical courses such as :
    • Lamellar Icthyosis- Shedding of the collodion membrane is followed by the development of large dark grey/brownish scales affecting the trunk and the scalp, but sparing the face and extremities
    • Bathing Suit Icthyosis - Born as collodion babies, they later develop a lamellar type of ichthyosis that spares the face and the extremities, and follows the distribution pattern of bathing suits.
    • Congenital ichthyosiform Erythroderma
    • Self‐healing collodion baby 
    • Acral self‐healing collodion baby

Note: Several syndromic types of congenital ichthyosis such as trichothiodystrophy or Gaucher syndrome type 2 also typically present as collodion baby.

questions.text: 31 year old unmarried female is diagnosed with a non palpable breast lesion on routine investigations. Pathological specimen after breast conservation surgery reveals it to be a 0.9 cm tumour in greatest dimension with negative sentinel lymph node and no distant metastasis. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of the disease is pT1b sN0 M0. 

Lets analyse and arrive at the staging :

Tumor staging - pT1b :

  • T1b is for tumours less than 1cm but > 0.5 cm. 
  • The prefix 'p' is added since it is a pathological.

Node staging - sN0 :

  • This is a node negative tumour and hence it is staged N0
  • Since the same is also confirmed using sentinel lymph node biopsy , the prefix 's' is added.

Metastasis staging - M0 :

  • Since there are no distant metastasis , it is staged M0.

 

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with primary hyperparathyroidism is undergoing a focused parathyroidectomy. How can one confirm that adequate parathyroid gland has been removed?

choices.text: PTH falls >20% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >50% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >10% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >30% within 10 minutes of removal of gland

questions.solution:
Adequate removal of parthyroid gland can be confirmed by a fall of >50% in PTH levels within 10 mins of removal of the gland.

Most patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. Therefore, they undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay as suggested by Miami criteria.

Miami criteria are based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: An elderly paraplegic patient admitted to a nursing home, developed an ulcer on her gluteal region. All of the following are true regarding the management of this patient except:

choices.text: Diet and nutritional support should aim to establish a positive nitrogen balance
Following debridement, exposure of the wound is recommended
Tensor fascia lata flap with an intact nerve supply may be used for covering the defect
Frequent change in position and air mattresses can help in preventing further sores

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a grade 3 bedsore. A grade 3 pressure sore requires dressing following debridement.

Preoperative management involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure. Alginates, foams, hydrocolloids, hydrogels are other options that are available.

The aim of surgery is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh).

Nutritional optimization with high caloric and protein diet should be done to establish a positive nitrogen balance. Frequent changes in position and air mattresses can also help in preventing further sores.

questions.text: Which is not true about the surgical position shown in the image?

choices.text: It is the best surgical position for CNS procedures specially posterior fossa surgeries
It ensures a relatively bloodless field during surgery
It can also be used for breast reconstruction
It decreases the risk of air embolism during surgery

questions.solution:
The fowlers position increases the risk of air embolism during surgery.

Fowlers position:

  • It is the best surgical position for CNS procedures specially posterior fossa surgeries
  • It ensures a relatively bloodless field during surgery
  • It can also be used for breast reconstruction.

https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/761367-overview

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenetic hallmark for filovirus infections?

choices.text: There is a pronounced suppression of immune system.
DIC causes severe imbalance in the clotting system.
Extensive necrosis/hypoxic infarcts are seen in target tissues, particularly the gonads, kidneys, liver, and spleen.
It is associated with severe lymphocytosis.

questions.solution:
Severe lymphopenia is seen in patients with filovirus infections.

Filoviruses are a long, thread-like virus, hence the name.

Predominantly pleomorphic filaments but also assume torus- or 6-like shapes (width, ~80 nm; average length, ≥790 nm). 

Ebola virus and Marburg viruses, which cause hemorrhagic fever, belong to the genus filovirus.

  • The first targets of filovirus are local macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • One of the pathogenetic hallmarks of filovirus infections is a pronounced suppression of the immune system. It causes severe disturbance of the clotting system and the impairment of vascular integrity. Disseminated intravascular coagulation is the cause of the severe imbalance in the clotting system of filovirus-infected patients.

The FDA recently approved Ervebo, the first FDA-approved vaccine for the prevention of Ebola virus disease (EVD), caused by Zaire ebolavirus in individuals 18 years of age and older.

questions.text: Identify the part of fungi depicted in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows basidiospores, which are sexual spores formed on a basidium or base.

Fungi can be classified systematically based on the sexual spore formation into 4 classes:

  1. Phycomycetes: These are lower fungi with non septate hyphae
    1. Asexual spores - Sporangiospores
    2. Sexual spores - oospores, zygospores
  2. Ascomycetes: These include yeasts and filamentous fungi, have septate hyphae.
    1. Asexual spores – conidia
    2. Sexual spores – ascospores present in an ascus (sac).
  3. Basidiomycetes: They have septate hyphae
    1. Asexual spores – conidia
    2. Sexual spores – basidiospores on a basidium or base.
  4. Fungi imperfecti: Also known as deuteromycetes or hyphomycetes are fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes to the OPD requesting medications to quit smoking. He complains about feeling helpless and hopeless most of the time since years and also reports having suicidal ideations. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case is well motivated to quit smoking however the patient is suffering from depression and hence the drug of choice is Bupropion (depressed patient wishing to quit smoking).

  • A sustained-release preparation of the antidepressant bupropion improves abstinence rates among smokers and remains a useful option. However, Bupropion decreases the seizure threshold and should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Varenicline, a partial agonist at the α4β2 subtype of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, reduces cigarette craving and improves long-term abstinence rates. It has high receptor affinity, thus blocking access to nicotine, so if the treated smoker relapses, there is hardly any reward, and abstinence is more likely to be maintained.
  • The nicotine withdrawal syndrome can be alleviated by nicotine replacement therapy (e.g., nicotine inhaler and nasal spray, nicotine gum or lozenge, or nicotine transdermal patch). These methods suppress the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. However, most resume smoking over the ensuing weeks or months.
  • The cannabinoid CB1 receptor inverse agonist rimonabant improves abstinence rates and reduces the weight gain seen frequently in ex-smokers. It was found to be linked to depressive and neurologic symptoms and is not approved by the FDA.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Congenital zikavirus infection causes microcephaly, not macrocephaly. 

Zikavirus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, sexual and blood-borne transmission is also observed. Humans are the only reservoir. Vertical transmission from an infected mother can occur throughout gestation and commonly results in fetal death. Other complications include neural tube defects, sensorineural deafness, microcephaly, and ocular abnormalities.

Affected adults present with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, and rash, similar to dengue fever. Non-purulent conjunctivitis and palatal petechiae may also be seen. Complications though rare include Guillain-Barre syndrome, leukopenia, encephalitis, and thrombocytopenic purpura. It can persist in the testes for up to 160 days, making sexual transmission possible during this period.

It is diagnosed by RT-PCR which detects viral RNA. There are no curative or preventive antivirals or licensed vaccines available as of yet.

questions.text: Iodine 131 MIBG scan is useful in imaging all of the following tumors except
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma cannot be imaged using Iodine 131 MIBG scan.It is not a neuroendocrine tumor.

MIBG scintigraphy is used to image :

Tumors of neuroendocrine origin, particularly those of the neuroectodermal (sympatho-adrenal) system :

  • Pheochromocytoma, paragangliomas, neuroblastoma
  • Carcinoids
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) is taken up and concentrated by vesicles in the adrenal medullar cells because its structure is similar to norepinephrine.

Normal adrenal cortex tissue however does not take up appreciable MIBG.

questions.text: The marked area given in the sleep polysomnography is of ______
questions.solution:
The marked area in the given polysomnography represents REM sleep.

The three zones in the given image represent EOG, EEG and EMG, respectively.

The following table helps identify the state of wakefulness from the graph :

    EEG EOG EMG
Active state   Fast   +   +
REM sleep  Mixed    +   -
NREM sleep   Slow   -   +

 

In the marked area,

  • EOG shows Positive activity
  • EEG shows Mixed waves
  • EMG shows Minimal activity

This is characteristic of REM sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Acanthamoeba?

choices.text: It is a non oppurtunistic organism

questions.solution:
Acanthamoeba culbertsoni exists as trophozoite from and resistant cystic form, both these forms are infective.

  • It is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen
  • Human beings acquire by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes.
  • The trophozoite is large, 20–50 μm in size and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).
  • It presents as two chronic conditions- Acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.
  • Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology and culture. Growth can be obtained from corneal scrapings inoculated on nutrient agar, overlaid with live or dead Escherichia coli and incubated at 30 °C.

questions.text: Clinical finding seen in hypermagnesemia is
questions.solution:
Hypermagnesimia causes bradycardia and hypotension (like neurogenic shock).

Causes -

  • Excessive magnesium intake
    • A. Cathartics, urologic irrigants
    • B. Parenteral magnesium administration
  • Rapid mobilization from soft tissues
    • A. Trauma, shock, sepsis
    • B. Cardiac arrest
    • C. Burns
  • Impaired magnesium excretion
    • A. Renal failure
    • B. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Other
    • A. Adrenal insufficiency
    • B. Hypothyroidism
    • C. Hypothermia

Clinical features -

  • The most prominent clinical manifestations of hypermagnesemia are vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade.
  • Hypotension is refractory to vasopressors or volume expansion may be an early sign.
  • Nausea, lethargy, and weakness may progress to respiratory failure, paralysis, coma, with hypoactive tendon reflexes, paradoxical bradycardia and heart block may be seen.

ECG: Prolongation of PR, QRS, and QT intervals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about G-protein-coupled receptors?

choices.text: G proteins bind to hormones on the cell surface.
All the three subunits alpha, beta and gamma should bind to each other for G proteins to act.
G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.
G protein is bound to GTP in resting state.

questions.solution:
G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit. 

  • Excitatory - Gs and Gq 
  • Inhibitory - Gi 

In the resting-state:

  • G protein is a heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta, and gamma subunits. It forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones. G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP. 

The binding of ligand results in activation of GPCR, following which:

  • The alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP occurs
  • GTP-bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both the alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated.

Other options: 

Option A: G proteins do not directly bind to hormones or signaling molecules. Hormones or ligands bind to the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which is a transmembrane protein on the cell surface. The GPCR, once activated by the hormone, then interacts with the G protein to initiate signaling. 

Option B: In the resting state, the G protein exists as a trimer (alpha, beta, and gamma subunits bound together). However, for the G protein to act, it must dissociate into two parts: the alpha subunit and the beta-gamma dimer. This dissociation occurs when the G protein is activated (GTP replaces GDP on the alpha subunit). 

Option D: In the resting state, the G protein is bound to GDP (guanosine diphosphate), not GTP. When a ligand activates the GPCR, the receptor causes the G protein to exchange GDP for GTP. This exchange triggers the activation of the G protein, leading to the dissociation of the alpha subunit from the beta-gamma dimer. The G protein is considered active only when bound to GDP..

questions.text: Metabolic complications in CRF includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Hyperphosphatemia is seen in uremia and not hypophosphatemia.

Electrolyte abnormalities in uremia -

A) Hypernatremia(more common) and hyponatremia

B) Hyperkalemia (more common) and hypokalemia (rarely seen)

C) Hyperphosphatemia - A strong association between hyperphosphatemia and increased cardiovascular mortality rate in patients with CKD has been observed.

D) Hypocalcemia (increased risk of osteopetrosis and fracture), rarely hypercalcemia (in advanced CKD leading to calciphylaxis)

E) Metabolic acidosis

F) Hyperuricemia

Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) is a devastating condition seen almost exclusively in patients with advanced CKD. It is heralded by livedo reticularis and advances to patches of ischemic necrosis, especially on the legs, thighs, abdomen, and breasts due to vascular occlusion in association with extensive vascular and soft tissue calcification.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.

Agents that can be used as first-line for CML are:

  • Imatinib
  • Dasatinib
  • Nilotinib 

Dasatinib and nilotinib can be used in newly diagnosed cases of CML, that are found to be imatinib-resistant.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male comes with fever, maculopapular lesions over the face and red-eye. On examination, he has unilateral LMN facial palsy. The chest X-ray and computed tomography of the head are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows mediastinal widening and possible mediastinal lymph node enlargement. The CT shows a bilateral parotid enlargement. This along with red eyes (anterior uveitis) and LMN facial palsy suggests Heerfordt's syndrome denoting acute sarcoidosis.

One-third of patients with sarcoidosis may present with skin lesions like erythema nodosum, maculopapular rashes, hypo-hyper pigmented lesions.

Lupus pernio is a specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks, which is diagnostic of chronic sarcoidosis. Hence the lesion is not Lupus pernio.

Lofgren's syndrome is also a form of acute sarcoidosis presenting with erythema nodosum, arthritis and bilateral lymphadenopathy.

Mumps is not associated with facial palsy.

Tolosa Hunt syndrome consists retro orbital or unilateral peri orbital pain associated with ophthalmoparesis of the 3rd, 4th, 6th cranial nerves with pain relief after beginning corticosteroid.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man who is a known smoker presented with complaints of fatigue, flank pain, and bipedal edema. Serum biochemistry showed an increase in liver enzyme values and urine microscopy was suggestive of microscopic hematuria. CT abdomen is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and CT is suggestive of Renal cell carcinoma presenting with Stauffer syndrome.

Stauffer syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen in Renal cell carcinoma. It is a non metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6.

Stauffer syndrome is characterised by

  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Raised Alkaline phosphatase
  • Hypergammaglobilinemia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings are unlikely to be present in a patient with hyperkalemia?
questions.solution: Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia.

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis is:

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. 

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which acidosis occurs because of the inability of the tubules of the kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance. In this disorder, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is relatively well-preserved.

The defect is either inability to excrete hydrogen ions (inadequate generation of new bicarbonate ions) or inadequate reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. 

Types of RTA:

  • Type I - distal RTA or classical RTA is characterised by the inability to excrete H+ ions by the distal nephron. The urinary pH is >5.5, as the urine cannot be fully acidified, despite systemic acidosis. 
  • Type II - proximal RTA is characterised by the inability to reabsorb filtered bicarbonate by the proximal tubule.
  • Type III - mixed type, similar to both type I and II.
  • Type IV - is the most common type of RTA in clinical practice. This is a disorder of hyperkalemia, that occurs due to decreased aldosterone, which inhibits ammonium production.

The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anions and cations. The normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types of RTA is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal. This kind of metabolic abnormality is also seen in gastrointestinal losses.

questions.text: Tiagabine has been initiated as an adjunctive treatment for focal seizures in a patient. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Tiagabine acts by inhibiting the GAT1 GABA transporter, thereby reducing its reuptake into neurons. It also increases the duration of inhibitory impulses in the synapse by prolonging the action of GABA.

Tiagabine is approved as an add-on therapy for refractory partial seizures with or without generalization.

Other antiepileptic drugs that have GABA enhancing activity are vigabatrin and stiripentol.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is
questions.solution:
Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Cushing Reflex

  • When ICP is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised
  • The local hypoxia and hypercapnia causes an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration
  • The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla

questions.text: Not true about ghrelin is
questions.solution:
Ghrelin-Hunger hormone:

Ghrelin produced by the oxyntic gland area of the stomach and  is primarily involved in the central control of food intake.

It is also secreted by pancreas and adrenal glands.

Functions

  • Increases appetite/food intake (orexigenic)
  • It stimulates growth hormone secretion by directly acting on anterior pituitary
  • It increases gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility to prepare the body for food intake
  • It regulates the distribution and rate of use of energy
  • It inhibits leptin release. It also causes lipolysis

Ghrelin levels increase during fasting, peaking just before food intake begins or when the subject is expecting a meal.The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding.

Ghrelin is increased in Prader-willi syndrome.

Regulators of Appetite

Adipocyte derived

  • Leptin

Gut peptides

  • Stomach - Ghrelin
  • Small intestine - Peptide YY , CCK

Hypothalamic peptides

  • Neuropeptide Y(NPY)
  • Melanin concentrating hormone (MCH)
  • α- Melanocyte stimulating hormone (α-MSH)
  • Agouti-related peptide (AgRP)

questions.text: According to AIIMS protocol,all of the following are true about parenteral nutrition in a neonate except

choices.text: Administration of Dextrose concentration greater than 12.5%  through peripheral line should be avoided
To increase the glucose infusion rate, simultaneous insulin infusion should be used
Position of central line should be confirmed by X-ray before starting infusion
Venous access for Parenteral nutrition should not be interrupted for giving antibiotics or other medications

questions.solution:
Insulin infusion should not be used to increase the glucose infusion rate. However,if infant is developing high glucose levels despite glucose infusion rate of 4-6 mg/kg/minute, insulin infusion can be started.

Use of insulin to achieve higher glucose infusion rate and promote growth has been associated with lactic acidosis.

The goal of nutrition management in neonates, especially very low birth weight (VLBW) infants is the achievement of postnatal growth at a rate that approximates the intrauterine growth of a normal fetus at the same postmenstrual age.

Indications of parenteral nutrition
  • Birth weight less than 1000 g
  • Birth weight 1000-1500 g and anticipated to be not on significant feeds for 3 or more days
  • Birth weight more than 1500 g and anticipated to be not on significant feeds for 5 or more days
  • Surgical conditions in neonates: Necrotizing enterocolitis, Gastroschisis, Omphalocele, Tracheo- esophageal fistula, Intestinal atresia, Mal-rotation, Short bowel syndrome, and Meconium ileus

Option A-Dextrose concentration greater than 12.5% needs to be administered through central line

Option C-Position of central line should be confirmed by X-ray before starting infusion, to avoid risk of pericardial tamponade, tip of the central catheter should lie outside the pericardial sac (on the chest x-ray is at least 0.5 cm outside the cardiac outline)

Option D-To prevent Hospital-acquired infection (HAI), venous access for Parenteral nutrition should not be interrupted for giving any other medications.

Note-Trace elements like zinc, copper, manganese, selenium, fluorine and iodine should be provided in PN solutions.Zinc is universally recommended from day one of TPN, whereas the other trace minerals are generally provided after 2 weeks of TPN without any appreciable enteral feeding.

questions.text: Identify the gauge of the cannula shown below.

The 20 gauge cannula is colored pink

questions.text: Triple test for the diagnosis of DOWN syndrome includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Triple test for the diagnosis of DOWN syndrome includes AFP, HCG and Estriol.

In Down syndrome AFP is decreased, HCG is increased and Estriol is decreased.

questions.text: Which among the following statement is not true regarding pharmacokinetics of heparin?

choices.text: Heparin clearance is mainly extra renal
In circulation heparin mainly binds to endothelium
At low doses, heparin  binds rapidly to the endothelium.
After depolymerization , the longer chains are secreted back in to circulation.

questions.solution:
Heparin binds to macrophages which internalize and depolymerize the long heparin chains, and secrete shorter chains back into circulation.

  • Heparin clearance is mainly extrarenal 
  • In circulation, heparin binds to the endothelium and to plasma proteins in addition to antithrombin.
  • Clinical correlate:
    • Heparin binding to endothelium explain its dose dependent clearance
    • At low doses, heparin has a short half life as it binds rapidly to the endothelium.
    • At higher doses, heparin is cleared more slowly as endothelium binding gets saturated.

questions.text: A morbidly obese, diabetic woman did not respond well to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
The most suitable drug to reduce this patient's blood glucose level is canagliflozin.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in blood glucose levels. 

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide (GLP-1 agonist) cannot be used as it is can be given only parenterally and the patient insists on taking medications via the non-parenteral route.

Option B: Sitagliptin cannot be given since the drug increases the risk of fatal and non-fatal pancreatitis. The patient is already suffering from pancreatitis.

Option D: Pioglitazone is associated with bladder cancer. The patient has a family history of bladder cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.solution:
Mucus-secreting goblet cells ( not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus, as there is intestinal metaplasia of esophagus. Foveolar cells are the mucus-secreting cells in the stomach.

Barrett esophagus :

  • It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus (normal squamous epithelium is replaced by columnar cells).
  • It occurs due to chronic irritation of esophagus eg. GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease).
  • As the esophageal epithelium is not capable of handling the gastric acid, it changes to the columnar type, which is seen in the intestine (it can tolerate acid effects). Hence the mucus secreting goblet cells are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Alician blue is used in the staining of the biopsy specimen, as it stains the goblet cells. Mucicarmine is the specific stain.
  • As all the metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible. Whereas only 0.2 to 1% of Barrett's esophagus leads to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient of myocardial infarction died on the way to the hospital. During autopsy triphenyl tetrazolium chloride staining of the heart is done. What will be the color of the viable myocardium?
questions.solution:
The viable myocardium stains red with triphenyl tetrazolium chloride, because of the presence of lactate dehydrogenase enzyme.

The infarcted area is left unstained (pale yellow) due to leakage of the enzyme.

Old scars appear white and glistening.

choices.text: It is a programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development
The goals are to achieve improvement in neonatal mortality
Launched on the date of International Women's Day 2018
Targets to reduce low birth weight by 2% per annum

  • adolescent girls
  • pregnant women
  • lactating mothers 

The logo is:

The following image depicts the targets of this mission:
