The National Nutrition Week is an annual event, observed from 1 to 7 September every year initiated by the Food and Nutrition Board. The main objective is to raise awareness on the importance of nutrition for health which has an impact on development, productivity, economic growth, and ultimately national development.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing hypertension develops left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following transcription factors do not play a role in this?
questions.solution:
HNF is a transcription factor involved in the development of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), not the development of cardiac hypertrophy.

The transcription factors involved in cardiac muscle hypertrophy are:

  • GATA4 – hypertrophic stimuli result in enhanced DNA-binding activity of GATA-4
  • MEF2- increases due to pressure and volume overload
  • NFAT (Nuclear Factor for Activated T-cells)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).

3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: What is frustrated phagocytosis?

choices.text: Release of lysosomal contents due to damaged membrane
Engulfment of infectious pathogens and degradation by phagolysosome
Release of lysosomal enzymes when phagocytes cannot engulf targets

questions.solution:
The term frustrated phagocytosis refers to the release of large amounts of lysosomal contents into the external environment due the inability of the phagocytes to engulf.

When immune complexes are deposited on relatively flat immovable surfaces, the phagocytes are unable to surround and ingest them. In this case, the activation signals lead to an uncontrolled release of the lysosomal contents, despite lack of phagocytosis. This is known as frustrated phagocytosis. 

Other processes may lead to the release of lysosomal contents into the external environment:

  • Controlled secretion of granule contents - normal response of activated leukocytes
  • Damage to the phagolysosome membrane by certain phagocytosed substances like urate crystals

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the RAS gene except:

choices.text: Ras oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP binding  proteins.
There are 3 Ras genes in humans  H-RAS, K-RAS, N-RAS .
When Ras is switched on, it is involved in cell growth, differentiation and survival.
Mutations in ras genes need incoming signals for over growth of the cells

questions.solution:
RAS protoncogene :

  • The 3 Ras genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer.
  • Ras oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction).
  • When Ras is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately turn on genes involved in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.
  • Mutations in ras genes can lead to the production of permanently activated Ras proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

questions.text: Di Gugliemo disease is _____
questions.solution:
AML M6 or Acute Erythroid leukemia is known as Di Gugliemo disease.

AML M6/Acute erythroid leukemia

  • 1% of AML cases
  • Two subtypes: erythroid/myeloid leukemia (M6a, more common) or pure erythroid leukemia (M6b, rare)

Erythroid/myeloid leukemia (M6a)

  • >50% of nucleated marrow cells are of erythroid lineage, including erythroblasts, 20%+ of nonerythroid cells are myeloblasts
  • Dyserythropoiesis is prominent

Pure erythroid leukemia (M6b)

  • >80% erythroid precursors
  • Also called erythemic myelosis, Di Guglielmo disease syndrome: nonspecific clinical findings of anemia, thrombocytopenia, variable neutropenia

Positive stains

  • Erythroid cells: glycophorin A (mature forms), hemoglobin A, CD36, CD71, CD117(dim), PAS (vacuoles)

Remember:

  • Schilling type –AML M5
  • Naegli type –AML M4

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with fatigue, weight loss and heaviness in left hypochondrium for 6 months. The hemogram showed Hb, 10 gm/dL, TLC 5.5 lakhs/mm3, platelet count 4 lakhs/mm3, DLC (neutrophil 55%, lymphocytes 4%, monocytes 2%, basophils 6%, metamyelocytes 10%, myelocytes 18%, promyelocytes 2% and blasts 3%. ) , with following peripheral smear. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the symptoms, differential count is Chronic myelogenous leukemia. 

  • Clinical features
    • CML is primarily a disease of adults but also occurs in children and adolescents. The peak incidence is in the fifth to sixth decades of life.
    • The presence of a chimeric BCR-ABL is created by a reciprocal (9;22)(q34;q11) translocation (the so-called Philadelphia chromosome [Ph]).This is detected by cytogenetics, FISH or PCR.
    • Mild-to-moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia.
    • The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. 
    • Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction.
    • Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.
    • Peripheral blood - Leukocytosis, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 which consists predominantly of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
    • Blasts usually make up less than 10% of the circulating cells.
    • Platelets - usually increased
    • Marrow -The marrow is markedly hypercellular because of massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors, which usually include an elevated proportion of eosinophils and basophils.
    • Megakaryocytes are also increased and usually include small, dysplastic forms.
    • Erythroid progenitors are present in normal or mildly decreased numbers.
    • Increased deposition of reticulin is typical, but overt marrow fibrosis is rare early in the course.
    • Low LAP score

questions.text: What is total communication used for?
questions.solution:
The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of hearing-impaired children.

It requires the incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aneurysm formation due to defective elastin?
questions.solution:
Loeys–Dietz syndrome leads to aneurysm formation due to defective elastin (due to a defect in TGF-β signalling pathway).

Aneurysms are caused due to structural or functional defects in the connective tissue of the vascular wall. The following conditions cause intrinsic defects in connective tissue leading to aneurysm formation:

Syndrome Defect in
Loeys–Dietz syndrome Synthesis of elastin and collagens I and III
Ehlers–Danlos syndrome Synthesis of type III collagen in some subtypes
Marfan syndrome Synthesis of the protein fibrillin causing weakening of elastic tissue
Scurvy (vitamin C deficiency) Collagen cross-linking

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding the type of lymphoma which has maximum area of necrosis _____

choices.text: It is the least common type
RS cell are CD15+ and CD30+
RS cells are infected with EBV in 90% of cases Poor prognosis

questions.solution:
Lymphocyte depleted subtype of Hodgkin Lymphoma is associated with maximum necrosis of the Lymph nodes.

Lymphocyte depleted

  • Least common (<5%)
  • Older age
  • HIV infected individuals
  • Systemic symptoms present
  • There is paucity of lymphocytes and a relative abundance of Reed-Sternberg cells or their pleomorphic variants.
  • RS cell are CD15+ and CD30+
  • RS cells are infected with EBV in 90% of cases
  • Poor prognosis

questions.text:
1)	Which of the following is the correct order of steps in disaster management and response?
A – Response
B – Rehabilitation
C – Disaster Impact
D – Mitigation
questions.solution:
The steps of disaster management are disaster impact --> response --> rehabilitation --> mitigation.

  • Disaster impact and response includes: Search, rescue and first aid (must be done first), field care, triage, tagging and identification of dead
  • Rehabilitation or recovery includes: Water supply, sanitation and personal hygiene, food safety and vector control.
  • Mitigation: Measures designed to either prevent hazards or reduce the effects of the disaster leading to disaster preparedness.

questions.text: Mediterranean fever is a type of ________.
questions.solution: Familial Mediterranean fever is the most common heredofamilial amyloidosis. It is autosomal recessive and there is excessive production of cytokine IL-1 in response to inflammatory stimuli. The gene associated with this condition encodes a protein called pyrin. The amyloid fibrils here is made up of AA proteins.

questions.text: A new genetic syndrome has been defined and its etiology is being debated by many scholars all around the world. Which of the following would be the study of choice for formulating an aetiological hypothesis of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is the study of choice for formulating an aetiological hypothesis of disease.

Descriptive study:

Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population.

Procedures in descriptive studies

  • Defining the population to be studied
  • Defining the disease under study
  • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
  • Measurement of disease
  • Comparing with known indices
  • Formulation of an aetiological hypothesis

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: which among the following statements is false about follicular lymphoma ?

choices.text: Under expression of Bcl -2 apoptosis regulator.
In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
Follicular lymphoma

  • Arises from germinal center B cells
  • Usually, presents in the middle age.

Clinical features

Lymph node biopsy

questions.text: which among the following statements regarding emphysema is false:

choices.text: Centriacinar emphysema is the most common form.
panacinar emphysema underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults
panacinar is involvement of only from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.
Centriacinar emphysema occurs predominantly in heavy smokers, often in association with chronic bronchitis

questions.solution:
Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema emphysema probably underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults

Emphysema is classified into four major types: (1) centriacinar, (2) panacinar, (3) paraseptal, and (4) irregular.

  • Centriacinar (centrilobular) emphysema
    • Centriacinar emphysema is the most common form.
    • In this type of emphysema, the central or proximal parts of the acini, formed by respiratory bronchioles, are affected, whereas distal alveoli are spared. Thus, both emphysematous and normal airspaces exist within the same acinus and lobule.
    • The lesions are more common and usually more severe in the upper lobes, particularly in the apical segments.
    • Inflammation around bronchi and bronchioles is common.
    • In severe centriacinar emphysema, the distal acinus may also be involved, making differentiation from panacinar emphysema difficult.
    • Centriacinar emphysema occurs predominantly in heavy smokers, often in association with chronic bronchitis (COPD). 
  • Panacinar (panlobular) emphysema
    • In this type, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.
    • The prefix “pan” refers to the entire acinus, not the entire lung.
    • In contrast to centriacinar emphysema, panacinar emphysema tends to occur more commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases.
    • This type of emphysema is associated with α1 deficiency.
  • Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema
    • In this type, the proximal portion of the acinus is normal, and the distal part is predominantly involved. The emphysema is more striking adjacent to the pleura, along the lobular connective tissue septa, and at the margins of the lobules.
    • It occurs adjacent to areas of fibrosis, scarring, or atelectasis and is usually more severe in the upper half of the lungs.
    • The characteristic findings are of multiple, continuous, enlarged airspaces from less than 0.5 cm to more than 2.0 cm in diameter, sometimes forming cystlike structures.
    • This type of emphysema probably underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults
  • Airspace enlargement with fibrosis (irregular emphysema)
    • Irregular emphysema, so named because the acinus is irregularly involved, is almost invariably associated with scarring. In most instances, it occurs in small foci and is clinically insignificant.

Pathogenesis

  • TGFB gene exhibits polymorphisms that influence susceptibility to the development of COPD by regulating the response of mesenchymal cells to injury. For example, with certain polymorphisms, mesenchymal cell response to TGF-β signalling is reduced, which in turn
  • Results in inadequate repair of elastin injury caused by inhaled toxins.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), especially MMP-9 and MMP-12, have also been shown to have a pathogenic role in emphysema.
  • MMP-9 gene polymorphisms and higher levels of both MMP-9 and MMP-12 have been found in some emphysema patients.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who has been operated on for craniopharyngioma presents with polyuria and polydipsia. On investigation, the serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 250 mOsm/kg.  The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) level is normal. What could be the cause?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ↑serum osmolality and ↓urinary osmolality, after a cranial surgery, suggests a diagnosis of post-surgical central diabetes insipidus (DI). Irreversible central DI follows most cases of complete resections of craniopharyngioma.

Serum osmolality of >295 mOsm/L (normal: 280-295 mOsm/L) and the urine osmolality of <300 mOsm/L (normal: 500-850mOsm/L) are suggestive of DI. A water deprivation test is done to further classify the types of DI.  

Option A: In postoperative patients, because of IV fluids there is an acute expansion of ECF volume. This suppresses high ADH activity and causes diuresis with normal serum osmolality.

Option B: In SIADH, serum osmolality is decreased.

Option D: In cerebral salt-wasting syndrome there is hypersecretion ANP and their levels are usually elevated.
